reviews.text:
Excellent food, drinks, and service.
I can't say they are strictly "French cuisine" because there are many traditional selections that aren't on the menu as well as other items that are definitely not French or even French inspired..
 That said, the food was great, the service was friendly, welcoming, and attentive.
  Will definitely be back and eager to recommend to others.

The staff (Yvette) was attentive and gave great recommendations when I was torn between items. Don't skip the seasonal cocktails, I loved my "blue moon" a citrusy White Russian style drink, tastes like a creamsicle! The salad I ordered could easily have been an entree. The Scallops were delicious; the juxtaposition in texture between the spiral cut squash, juicy scallops, and the crunch of the toasted prosciutto surprises and delights. To finish things off, the earl grey pavlova topped with fruit was a delicate and satisfying finish. I'll be back!
So glad Lafayette has a restaurant of this quality.  The food, the service, the entire experience is top notch.

Visited today for the first time and had brunch.  The brunch menu was fantastic!  SO much to choose from!  Everyone in my party was very happy with what they ordered.  Price point for brunch is more reasonable than the dinner menu.  Service was good and all the staff were very polite.

Ambiance leave a lot to be desired.  Kind of boring.  And the metal chairs are very uncomfortable!

Disappointed by the looks of the dinner menu.  I don't know that I'll bother with dinner, but I'll definitely return for brunch!

We had not known this restaurant was here! We parked, got out of the car and realized this restaurant was next to where we had parked. It was worth a try! Was it ever!

Relaxing atmosphere, well chosen selection of food on the menu, and an impressive wine list. 

The options are quite good! They were able to accommodate a keto diet. The food was tasty, of a high quality, and presented well. 

We will go back!

Have never had the same thing twice and have never been disappointed.  Last night I had the "Duck two ways" and both ways were delectable.  The presentation was as beautiful as the taste was divine.  (unfortunately it was so delicious i forgot to get a picture)
Folie is easily comparable to the finest establishments in Indianapolis but with Lafayette charm instead of big city attitude.  A wine selection to be envied, good craft beers on tap, and their cocktails are awesome.  This is the perfect place for special evenings but comfortable enough for a casual evening out.

Very disappointing. The experience started with the hostess being rude while sitting me at one of the tables. 

Ordered the Spanish octopus as an appetizer. Worst octopus I've ever had. It was so incredibly tough. No taste. The server saw that we didn't eat much and looked disappointed. No apologies. No taking it off out bill. Nothing.

The steak was average. Overpriced for what it was. 

Only had one option for desert that didn't sound appealing at all so we went elsewhere for desert.

I had the best food and service. Everything was perfect.  Rachel was terrific.  
They had a great selection of wines too.

We arrived for dinner on a Saturday evening. There were two other parties in our area when we arrived; one of those parties soon left. The interior is quite nice: lighting, carpeting, flooring, art, and the lay out of the space is quite cozy.  We were, at first, puzzled about why the place was so empty.  We ordered a cheese plate, which took a very long time to arrive, considering there weren't too many other people in the restaurant. The cheese was dry, and the fruit, which included some apple slices, tasted terrible. The apple, literally, tasted like someone had found it on the floor, sliced it up, and brought it out to us with the cheese.

Our other dishes were flavorful, but skimpy and all of the "hot" dishes arrived lukewarm.  This place definitely is trying to experiment with flavors, textures, and ingredients, but they just can't get the execution right.  These dishes, also, took a long time to arrive, given that we were the only guests in the dining room who had ordered.

The worst, though, was the staff.  No one was rude or deliberately unresponsive.  However, several of the staff members were talking very, very loudly about things like drug use, and using a lot of profanity when they spoke. The acoustics of the restaurant were such that it was almost impossible for me to have a conversation with my dining partner, and we could not wait to leave. It was a huge turn-off.  All of the staff with whom we had contact seemed very inexperienced, and from what we could tell (e.g., their very loud conversations), they are college students who are in the job for a paycheck, not because they are interested in hospitality as a career.

Very disappointing, and I'm not surprised that when we left, the dining area was +completely+ empty of guests. This, on a Saturday evening in the downtown area.

Folie presents French-influenced nouvelle(ish) cuisine in a relaxed atmosphere. We were greeted by a young staff that took excellent care of us throughout the night. The wine list is superb for Lafayette, IN with a range of options at different price points. 

Our appetizers were pork belly with sweetbreads, and steamed mussels with stilton and pernod. Both were infused with layers of complex flavors. 

For entrees we ordered pork tenderloin with barley risotto in a calvados sauce and a steak with duck fat potatoes. The barley risotto was a perfect complement to the pork and all tasted great in the sauce. The steak was well prepared but was maybe less of a standout by comparison. 

Desserts took on more of a molecular gastronomy flair with a deconstructed berry cheesecake that was to die for. We also tried the chocolate panna cotta; the flavors were excellent but the consistency was a little tough. 

All in all, Folie is a strong addition to the restaurant scene in Lafayette with upscale dining, delicious fresh food with innovative preparations, and a well curated wine list.

I visited Folie during the Christmas Parade. Not sure if it was because of the event, but the restaurant was more or less empty at 6:15 on Saturday. A few more parties came in during our meal, but it never came close to filling up.

The service was excellent. All the staff were kind, friendly, just great at their jobs. 

The menu was small. I appreciate that. I despise large menus. I want to choose from what a restaurant is best at...I don't want to wade through nine pages. 

We ordered a hot appetizer, a cold appetizer and two entrees. Respectively scallop, beet, lamb loin, monkfish/lobster

Prior to any of this we received the bread with truffle oil butter. Not a huge truffle fan, but it was pretty good, so that's a win. The complimentary tasting soup they brought was excellent. Lentil-based, I believe. Very good. Best thing we ate actually.

The hot appetizer was a single seared scallop. Naturally I don't want overcooked scallops, but this was not cooked in the middle at all. And what I don't get is why this "seared" scallop had no coloration on the top or bottom. Not much of a sear-job when there's no color and the inside isn't cooked. The sauce with it was good. The portion was microscopic.

Next was the "Beets". Not sure what i expected, but it was various types of beets. Not a beet fan, and these were beets. Need I say more? The beet sorbet was my favorite option. $13 for what amounted to a single beet. Who knew?

Monkfish was just ok. Lobster with it was good. Sauce was decent. Combined it didn't add up to more than the sum of the parts. Was just three different things. Again, small portion.

Lamb loin was cooked rare, tasted great, sauce was also pretty good. the meat portion here was ok, the sides were comically small. About two bites of zucchini and two bites of something else. Ridiculous.

We also had a couple Moscow Mules (they call them something fancier). Those were very good.

This restaurant has excellent service. I enjoyed my drink. I also thought the entrees tasted good. The serving sizes are very small, especially appetizers. 

This is easily the most pretentious restaurant in Lafayette. The presentation and ingredients of the meals seem to be more important than the taste. $130 for an ok meal is not ok in Lafayette. 

Folie seems to have no set menu. I believe the last two restaurants to try that  model in Lafayette were Restauration & Heirloom. Those one-year experiments didn't end well. 

I do like the idea of rotating a portion of the menu, but by rolling the entire thing over, you can't appeal to the people who are....*ahem*...boring eaters. There is one in every group (and most couples). If you can't always offer a few items that have mass appeal you're going to have trouble keeping guests coming back in a small city like Lafayette. It would make more sense to me if they were to keep a few broad-appeal, perfected dishes on the menu and rotate the rest. 

This restaurant seems like it would only make sense in a very large city. I don't see it making any sense whatsoever in Lafayette. It's borderline ridiculous, but I wish them the best. I would put the quality of the food on par with Black Sparrow or East End Grill, but at a much higher price point (but also with more weird ingredients)

Food/Price would be three stars, but the service was great and drinks were good, so I felt compelled to go with four stars.

Husband and I dined here last Thursday and LOVED it! Can't BELIEVE such a perfect restaurant has come to Lafayette but, boy, are we grateful! The dining room is understated elegance; special but not stuffy. The service is exactly how I like it: attending to your needs without trying to make chit-chat. You feel cared for but not hovered over. 

And the food...the FOOD! All ingredients were the best they could be and each dish was prepared, not just thrown together. I had the trout and my husband had the steak; both were excellent and each was tender. We had a hot appetizer and a cold one. The  pickled vegetables were generous and each vegetable had been pickled differently, making a simple offering interesting to eat. The turnip soup recipe elevated this winter root veggie into something you could CRAVE. (I still can't believe I said that about a turnip!)

We ordered wine by the glass (it was a Thursday) and it was a generous pour.

Didn't order dessert as we were full, but will go hungrier next time so we have room. The words "chocolate panna cotta" are calling to me.

The chef clearly has some big-city skills. We hope locals can appreciate him so he will stay. 

Our advice to locals? Forget the Bistro! Don't bother with Pure! Skip the noice at East End Grill! GO TO FOLIE and you'll have a new favorite!

Had a great time here last night. It can feel like there are limited options for a high class meal in town, and my girlfriend and I were excited to try something new. We'd definitely suggest this place for a nice date dinner. 

The atmosphere was quiet enough to feel calm and elevated, but loud enough to avoid feeling like a food mueseum. It was fairly empty when we arrived at 6:30, but by 7:00 it was pretty hopping. 

Food was great. I got the salmon and my gf got coq au vin. She clearly had the better dish, but mine was elevated and intriguing, combining unexpected flavors (green beans and pomegranate). I got the better dessert, a deconstructed cheesecake that was fun to work through. You can really see the chef thinking through the dishes in the menu, and that level of care added to the experience. 

We'll definitely come back. Can't wait to see what they add to the menu!

We had a wonderful dinner at Folie! Started with the beet and fig salad which was delicious and large enough to share. Hangar steak with potatoes and mushroom sauce was cooked perfectly and very flavorful. The lamb tagine on sweet potato purée and couscous was great. Wonderful combination of flavors. Topped off with the brownie special dessert which was very good and large enough to share. Brownie was not too sweet and the right amount of chocolate. The food was presented beautifully. Very pleasant staff. A special spot.

Went in for a drink on a Wednesday night. The place was hopping! We sat at the bar for a glass of wine and a bite to eat. Loved the ambiance. Excellent wine list. Plus the staff are so friendly. The shrimp and grits were delicious! I am so excited that Folie is here. I will be coming back for dinner ASAP!!

There's a new fine dining option in Lafayette, and it's excellent.

I went there with my wife, and liked it so much I took business associates there a few days later.

The bar is well stocked, with a wine and beer list that's not as big as some in town, but very well thought out. Wine options range from value bottles that would fit the budget of a grad student splurging on a once a quarter I can't stand ramen any more night to a wine aficionado looking for a good Rhone red. The bartender was friendly and knowledgeable without being intrusive.

The dinner menu was concise and well thought out, a range of appetizers that'd be great to use as "plates to share" for a group. The entrees cover the range from beef to seafood to vegetarian. I've tried fried oysters and the pork belly confit. Both were very good, but the pork belly confit was a luscious, perfectly prepared bite of porcine goodness, balanced by a not too tart, not too sweet dollop of tomato jam. Companions raved about the carrot soup and the wedge salad.

As an entrée, the hanger steak was an excellent piece of beef, prepared (I'm pretty sure sous vide) and seared to perfection. The house pickled mustard grains popped in my mouth, adding just the right amount of bitter and acid to offset the round fatty flavor of the beef.

The duck breast was likewise very good. Maybe just slightly overdone, but it had juicy, tasty meat with crisp, nicely seared skin and most of the fat rendered out. The sour cherry and hazelnuts added some crunch and a little acid, it'd be the perfect dish with an Oregon Pinot Noir.

I didn't try the scallops myself, but both nights I was there people at the next table raved about them, and they sure looked good. Have to save that for my next visit.

I've tried one desert there, a classic profiterole, or as my mom used to call them, a cream puff. Folie's are fresh made pâte à choux pastries filled with vanilla ice cream and topped with chocolate sauce.

I have only two quibbles. The front of the house staff were friendly and super eager to please, but still learning. I watched our server struggle with a corkscrew and wanted to help her, but she did get the job done. The second is that the salmon on the menu is farm raised. I'm sure that's an effort to keep prices down, but a chef this good deserves better material to work with. Go with Alaskan Kings guys.

Overall, this is a restaurant that would make it in New York or Chicago, but at prices that won't bust a Lafayette budget. Highly recommend!

Probably the best high class dining in the area. Sure, it is pricey, but if you want to treat your lady to something special, that's the place to go. We had the salmon and the steak which were both top class and I'd be surprise if any of their dishes are not first grade. My girlfriend and I, we both dislike sweets but the chocolate cake was the perfect finish for an over all great experience. Don't go if you're expecting to overeat, but if you want an extraordinary dining experience, this is the place.

PS: Their bar is as well outstanding. Great wine selection and the cocktails, from what I tried, are very well made.

We tried Folie on a Thursday after Science on Tap and it was a fun experience. A little pricey for what you're getting food wise, but it's got that sophisticated city feel to it. Unfortunately, I don't see it lasting long in Lafayette, just like many of the other cute fusion restaurants. Hopefully I am wrong, they made a great dirty martini!

The Parmesan Crusted Salmon was excellent and the wine selection was superb. 

The owners, John & Halie, went out of their way to stop by and spend the time to make sure everything was perfectly cooked.

It was also a fantastic atmosphere to just grab a drink as well. 

The best bourbon selection I've seen in Lafayette!

Best mussels I've ever had. Ladies liked the salmon. Chicken main was well prepared. Chef knows his business. Wine list was solid. Bar area is a bit loud in the dining area, though the quality of the food made up for it.

reviews.text:
Family ordered take out from here last night trying for the first time. Ordered online and got our order correct. For starters Pretzel Bread Sticks  with the white cheese were surprisingly good. Boom Boom Cauliflower was very good as well. Main Entrees: Hand Battered Chicken Tenders, CountryFried Chicken and the North Atlantic Fish were all really pretty good too! Wasn't sure when first looking at them as were pulling out of the bag but was pleasantly surprised. Everything tasted fresh and great flavor. Will say only downfalls we found was Mac and Cheese sides were really flavorless and tasted like plain noodles and the chocolate cake was very disappointing. Cheesecake was enjoyable though. 
Would definitely try again.

Very nice atmosphere and friendly staff. Service was quick, even when the restaurant was packed full of guests. I ordered the jerk chicken tacos. The plate itself was very appealing, flavor was there; although, the contents of the tacos were dry. Could have used some more sauce or more moist chicken. But would definitely return and probably order a different dish.

I never cared for Scotty's, so had higher hopes for the new Wolfie's. We try to give new places a couple of chances. And we will here, too. 

First off -- great customer service for takeout ordering. The woman taking our order was friendly and patient with questions. She was a bit unfamiliar with the menu, but we worked through it. And upon arrival, the food was ready and everything was there. So props for that. 

Do wish they had curbside pickup parking. Would make things much more convenient. 

Food wise -- the fried chicken and mashed potatoes with pepper gravy was really tasty. Five stars. And the coleslaw was really good, too. 

Sadly, the rest of the meal was less exciting. Shrimp tacos had plenty of shrimp, but it was not at all seasoned. There was an almost laughably small amount of avocado on each taco. Boom boom sauce was good, but the pico de gallo was overwhelmingly jalapeño. And that dominated every bit. It was like just eating a jalapeño straight with no flavor complexity at all. 

Similarly the jalapeño creamed corn (a fried chicken side) had no other flavor. The sweetness of the corn does not come through at all. Nothing but jalapeño. 

The Mac and cheese was dry and flavorless. It seemed like it might have a spicy kick to it, too? Or maybe our mouths were just burned by other dishes. Hard to say.

Tried Wolfies for takeout on a Thursday evening. We were going for a seafood theme seeing as how they have a bunch of seafood options. Calling in to put the order was easy. Food was ready in about 20 minutes. Wish they had curbside pickup. 
The food itself was decent. The blackened tilapia sandwich was good, with the boom boom sauce, but the fish and fries was not my favorite. On top of that, they separated the fish rather than leaving it whole. Definitely not a fan. Portion sizes were decent. Prices were okay but the food definitely didn't leave me wanting to come back for more.

First time inside a restaurant for two of us. Worried that sports bar atmosphere might equal boring food. Not so! Steak and shrimp perfect, salmon dish delicious, pan crusted chicken done just right! Generous sides included in very reasonable prices. Excellent server. We are not done with this restaurant!

Delicious food, great service, and welcoming atmosphere make this place a great new addition to Lafayette and West Lafayette. My burger was cooked perfectly and was excellent. The soy Brussel sprouts are delicious as well. My girlfriend said the pan crusted chicken was delicious too.

A decent replacement for the favorite area burger house called Scotty's we had for many years at this location. Wolfies offers an enticing menu with good options however prices and food size are not as ideal as Scotty's offered despite the extensive beverage options, fantastic service, and accommodating atmosphere with a dirty monotone color pallet covering the ceiling and bricks all over the walls. Our best part was the bang bang shrimp app! Super tasty and perfectly made, follows by the lesser dishes, my ahi tacos and my friend's buffalo wrap. Both well thought out, presenting solid appetizing flavors and smells, but ultimately not serving up a massive win to keep us out of other near by places like Town & Gown, The Pint, or Red Seven. My buddy wasn't a fan of the powerful wasabi in my tacos even though I loved it exactly for that! We both agreed the Buffalo wraps were small for the price and oddly (unlike my wasabi treated tacos) lacked the bite buffalo should have. The sides were very nice, mac and cheese and coleslaw did us both well. Our drinks were also fine however my cucumber gin and tonic blew the doors off the desserts and everything else we got alongside our main dishes. Speaking of desserts, I completely forget either of our dishes except by the photos it looks like we tried the cookie and monkey bread. I seem to recall they were both average. Overall this feels like a grown up Buffalo Wild Wings! A few hits but would be better having a good group to enjoy the game, know the best dishes before hand, and figure out what will get us full before assuming $14 tacos is a packed dinner meal.

We tried this place out on a weeknight.  Wife said her salmon was cooked to perfection. And the Brussels sprouts were great also.  Her broccoli was old and yellow tho.  I had crust pan chicken. It was ok but not anything special. Onion straws were my favorite. Mashed potatoes were average at best.  Overall. We probably won't b back .  Could have paid less with sirloin steak and such at Texas Roadhouse. But waitress was excellent help.
NEVER GET THE "NEW OLD FASHIONED". Other than that the food is great. Burgers are amazing, wings are awesome, and the meat falls right off the bone of the ribs.

We have been to wolfies in Indy quite a few times...the Geist location is great. This location...not really. Took over ten minutes to place a drink order. Food was just ok. I'm not impressed at all with this wolfies and probably won't go to this one again.

Had One of their signature fish dishes. The mashed potatoes were delicious and the fish was somewhat rubbery which would indicate that it wasn't fresh fish but frozen previously. The Decour inside the place is nice the staff was very friendly but I'll need to eat other food to decide whether not this place deserves a higher rating.
Great black and bleu burger! Cool atmosphere. Good service. I'll definitely be going back

This is located in what was formerly Scotties. The staff are prompt, there is indoor and outdoor dining, and the tables seem properly distanced or blocked off for social distancing.
The food is lacking. We got the soy brussell sprouts (way too salty), and other dishes that were unremarkable.

reviews.text:
Ok, so I've driven by this place so many times and never considered it. Don't be like me, stop and check it out! When I heard that they have California burritos on their menu, I  had to get one. I was not disappointed! The burrito had a generous amount of meat (Pastor for me), rice, lettuce, pico, guacamole, and French Fries! The taste was amazing, but it was wrapped a little sloppily. My teenagers enjoyed their nachos supreme, and breaded tenderloin. 

We called our order ahead of time, and it was ready in 15 minutes. I'm glad we did, because when we arrived to pickup, the order line was 4 cars deep (at 5pm on a Thursday!). This is totally going into our takeout rotation, there is something for everyone on their menu. The lady working the window (and phone) was super friendly and cheerful.

This place has fed me all quarantine and will continue to be a staple for years to come. Local and convenient. By far, the best menu item is the fresh jalapeño poppers. They are not for the weak as the heat is intense! 

I switch between the stuffed burger, the nachos and the other burgers they offer a lot. They have pulled pork nachos which are a favorite. Amazing owners who put heart into each order!! Victor does a great job! Next, I want to try their mangonadas!

We've been wanting to try their burgers for a few weeks now, but their opening hours are a little unusual so it's been closed whenever we've gone (call ahead!). 

We finally made it on a Saturday around 11.30am but realised that on Saturdays  they only serve one item (and that's till they run out) - Mexican Birria.
This is a stew that is normally made with lamb, but here they serve it with beef. You can have it in different styles: over fries, in a cup, as a taco or quesadilla. We decided to try it over fries (also comes with queso, guac, jalapeños). The beef is very tender and resembles pulled meat. The birria reminded me of Indian beef curries that I've had but not as spicy. The combo of the birria over the fries was yummy. The guac in particular was fantastic and I liked that they didn't go crazy with the queso - just the right amount. 

Overall, this is a yummy dish and worth trying if you've never had it before, but I can't say I loved it. We will definitely be going back to try their burgers which so many people seem to love. 

Service was great and the staff were super helpful.

I drove by a couple of weeks ago and saw a new tenant in the old shack, and I knew I had to stop in. After hearing a client talking about the food, that sealed it.

Nothing fancy, the Wicked Food Shack is just that, a shack serving wickedly good food. To order, you either use the walk-up window or drive-thru. The menu is fairly simple with burgers, hot dogs, tenderloin, fries, tacos, burritos, esquite (Mexican corn in a cup, I got to know it as elotes in Texas), and other goodies. The menu is ever expanding - look for some dessert items in the future. 

I had the stuffed burger, which comes with fresh cut fries. Cheddar cheese and chopped bacon are stuffed inside a hamburger patty and then cooked to perfection. Normally I don't order bacon on a burger because I don't get a good bite on a slice of bacon due to my weird uneven teeth. With the chopped bacon stuffed in the patty, I got all the bacon taste in each bite. No need for condiments on this burger, the juices do it all.

The thick fries are freshly cut, and the interior steams while in the fryer. The exterior is crispy while fluffy on the inside. 

I also had the chili cheese fries. The same fresh cut fries are slathered with cheese sauce and house made chili. Although not as spicy as I prefer, this chili will fit in well with the local palate. These fries would be a great snack when it's 10 degrees out.

The Wicked Food Shack is going into my lunch and dinner rotation, if just for the burgers and fries. I'm going to have to work my way through the menu.
The fried catfish sandwich is huge and filling and tasty! Was enough for my husband and I to share. The fries are seasoned well

On the surface, Wicked Food Shack looks very missable, I mean... hand written menu, total staff is two guys, location is a tiny building in parking lot... but boy can appearances be deceiving. The main event here is the burgers. The Wicked Burger boasts a really tasty hamburger patty, pulled pork and bacon. I know, right? The fries were tasty and plentiful. We also tried a jalapeño burger, which was great. The menu looked great, too, with a chili dog that looks to set the bar for chili dogs, and all sorts of other tasty odds and ends. And to boot, we ate there on National Burger Day. Only in America, folks. Only in America.

Make sure you try out the tacos on Saturday! Soooo good! Very friendly staff that really seem to care about the customer! They actually prepared the food how previous menus had it just because we asked about it! Can't wait to go back!

Mmmm let me let this food settle before I can continue this review.... do you hear the crickets... means the food is so good words can't even describe it! We had the fried blt and tenderloin. Something about this food reminded me of California, oh how I miss it! All I can say is... it's hands down yummy!! You definitely need to try it and please open up a wicked down down south or of Indy!! Ok, back to my food!

Food was amazing! So much better than fast food and wow just flavorful in every bite. 10/10 would recommend! Everything looked very clean and i cant wait to come back time and time again. Owners were very nice! Worth every penny and the prices were fair.

reviews.text: Such a great place! Ramen is amazing. When they say spicy, they mean it. Nice staff. Covid friendly, seats are similar to study hall cubbies.

Similar menu as the downtown Three Legged Crow, fantastic ramen! So good! The Miso Spicy is the answer to cloudy days, rain, hunger, sunny days, fun times, friends, family, it is so good. I always get it and have tried about half the other but none gets me like Miso Spicy. I'm all for the sushi burritos too however they're quite expensive. It's a tidy little campus spot with fun interaction ordering through a robot. There's cubicles that some may enjoy but others will feel confined. Not much window space but good for my sister and I we had it all to ourselves. Glad to have another ramen spot to spread out the space!
Sushi burritos are bomb and worth the money! Super cute and will be getting more soon!

The ordering and delivery process is disjointed but a throw back to actual ramen shops in Tokyo.  Food was good so worth the experience.  
Challenge is when during COVID only one group can be in the entranceway  and other li and e upbin freezing cold outside even when plenty of seats available in dining roon.

reviews.text: Still the best ideal mix of value and quality I have ever found, updating my review since trying T&G over 20 times - tragic that some people have a minor issue with a dish and form an entire opinion for a restaurant. Sure the menu is small, location and atmosphere on a budget, and parking is awkward (was a coffee shop originally) - the thing is: we do this hold back with menus. We end up conflicted. One item jumps out and tempts but we normally play it safe and go for the burger or some familiar item right? But pasta sounds tasty, haven't had good pasta for a long time. Right?! We all do this game. Why? Because the typical corporate food disappoints us 80% of the time. This is why I love Town & Gown. I have been here so many times with many of my family, friends, friend's friends, and gone thru most of the menu, not one bad time yet. This is the restaurant that is all about trying pasta, salmon, lamb, and more! No more burgers and salads snickering at you because you picked the Reuben (so predictable). Never mind, bad example, the Reuben here is fantastic. But that pasta, salmon, appetizers, deserts - it's the classic French style proving the chef knows what he's doing. OK - the breakfast is overpriced (like most places) and if you have complaints (which obviously can happen we had a salad once with dry chicken) ask the staff to fix it! I always leave here wondering why people go to Longhorn, East End Grill, Bistro 501, and other high class restaurants. You'll spend at least $20 more and end up with way less food. I guess eating under a shiny chandelier is worth the extra money for some. For the rest of us, T&G is a breath of fresh air. It will be everything you hoped for. The desert is crazy good too! Cheesecake better than Cheesecake Factory and half the price! Tiramisu like a massive slab of chocolate concrete soaked in espresso drugs. Apple pie, no words for the apple pie. Chocolate cake ripe for gluten-free darkness. The dinner prices are double what they were a few years ago but even $15 for a large fancy Pacific fish is way cheap. I'm real glad to see a proper chef surviving amidst a nasty mix of cheap college feeders and corporate restaurants all throwing enough sodium in their food to fill your FDA daily dose. I've seen a lot of uncomfortable health articles on the issues of that excess processed sodium. Hope to see Town & Gown continue to show off what fresh ingredients and real food should taste like.
Amazing and classy brunch spot. Probably one of the best in town for sure to get a good brunch! Drinks are unique and the coffee tastes rich and smooth like chocolate.

Being new in town, I was keen to try out a brunch place and this was recommended by a friend who used to live in the area. Got here around 1pm on a Sunday (we were a group of 6 with a dog). The waitress who initially served us seemed a bit frazzled and was slightly curt. We were asked to wait for about 5 minutes before a place outside became available.

The outdoor seating is really cute, lots of flowers and has a cozy feel. It definitely gets a little toasty but I'd highly recommend it, especially as I found that when waiting inside, the cooking/greasy smell from the kitchen wafts in and sticks to your hair and clothes. 

The guy who served us was very polite and friendly. They serve big, yummy cups of coffee (I loved their coffee). This is what we got:
1. Smoked salmon and croissant bennie: The smoked salmon was great. My only issue with this dish is that they pour hollandaise sauce over it as if it's gravy. Next time I'd just get this on the side so I can moderate how much I want over it. The hollandaise sauce was pretty decent, a little less thick than what I'm used to. The croissant bennie was yummy, but by the time you get through to it, it's completely soggy from all the hollandaise sauce. Eggs were perfectly done. 
2. T&G Reuben: Big portion. This was really yummy and well done. It comes with a side of their "home fries" which appear to be roast potatoes. The potatoes were well seasoned, but quite oily. 

Would I go back? Yes. I'd really like to try out their other brunch items and lunch/dinner menu.

I really loved this place whenever I would go. My husband got the vegan plate which said had rice but it was just steamed vegetables and I got the penne marinara. The noodles seemed like a few days old and the sauce smelled like it was rotten.

Whether you are looking for a great breakfast, lunch or dinner, Town and Gown Bistro will meet your needs. They offer both in and outside dining. Their menu offers a great variety of options. 
For brunch, I love their Smoked Salmon and Croissant Benny. Also be sure to try the Blood Orange Mimosa or the St. Germain cocktail. 
For lunch and dinner, I would recommend their specials or salmon dishes. Their sandwich options are also really good. 
The only downside to this restaurant is their tiny parking lot. During peak hours it can be really hard to find parking so beware.

Parking was easy and spacious. The place had big sign on the front so finding it was not a problem. I ate with a large group of people and it took them pretty quick to sit us.

I ordered the first item on their menu which was a classic eggs, bacon and toast breakfast. On top of that, they also gave me a huge pancake that I did not finish. The food was okay and the servers were friendly.

We stopped here on a cross country family road trip. I had the grilled salmon salad, my husband had an omelette, and my teens had the Gypsy chicken and sweet and savory pork. The portions were generous, the food fresh and the plates had lots of fresh vegetables which are hard to find on a road trip. The patio was lovely, covered in flowers and welcoming to our two dogs. The service was attentive. A great place for brunch.

Free parking is available behind the building although rather limited. They have my favorite Eggs Benedict and also a good deal on 1 pancake if I'm branching out from my Eggs Benedict. The coffee drinks often come in fun mugs, and the list of coffee cocktails is very fun for a boozy brunch.

Hosted an event here. And the staff here were wonderful! They made reservations easy. They let me come in early and get setup. We never felt rushed or in a hurry. And our dedicated server Shelby was awesome! I don't know how she did it but she stayed on top of our orders and our drink refills and she was so terrific to work with. Everyone loved their meal. I had the salmon and it was delicious!! I mean. It was delicious.

Waited too long to go to a local place. Brunch was fantastic. Eating outside on a beautiful fall day made it better. Service was excellent.  Millie was a professional that was right there if you needed something. She checked on drink refills and how we were enjoying our food after we had time to actually try it.  Well managed, clean, a spacious parking lot.  Egg dish, omelette were perfectly cooked. Good coffee.  Homemade cornbeef hash with mushrooms, onions, cheese was memorable.  Perfect location on the edge of Purdue campus. Looking forward to trying lunch or dinner.

A classic brunch stop in West Lafayette! The prices are super reasonable and the pancakes are probably the best pancakes I've had in a long time. I can't comment on the dinner but I've been for breakfast quite a few times and I am never disappointed. The biggest let down I have is their limited "weekend brunch" menu. There are only a handful of options available on the weekends for brunch and after trying the dishes multiple times, I'm ready to change it up a bit. Other than that, the place is delicious!

First time here, so tried the breakfast menu on a Sunday morning while eating outside.  Food was good and plentiful.  We ordered a smoked salmon omelet with wheat toast and the Bistro Egg Round (with sausage).  Service was good - we will be back.

I really want to like this place more, but have had some issues.  I like their menu.  I love all the salmon options they have for breakfast.  Their breakfast menu is more brunch-like in style.  There are very few places to brunch in Lafayette and West Lafayette and, those that do offer brunch, usually only do so on Sundays so I like the idea I can get a brunch quality meal any day of the week here.

Prices for food and drinks were reasonable.  My issue is that the food is inconsistent and not just between days where perhaps there may be a different chef, but on the very same day!  My first visit I ordered the smoked salmon eggs benedict and my friend ordered the homemade corned beef hash.  My eggs benedict arrived and they were SWIMMING in hollandaise sauce!  Now I though I loved hollandaise sauce, but there's certainly such thing as too much of a good thing.  You could barely even see my meal beneath all the sauce!  I couldn't taste anything but the sauce!  Yet I noticed other benedicts that same visit that other people ordered and they had a normal amount of sauce on them.

I tried my friend's homemade corned beef hash and it was delicious!  Lots of meat mixed with potatoes.  So, on my next visit, this is what I ordered.  Mine was nothing compared to hers though!  Whereas hers had lots of meat, mine was mostly potatoes.  I was very disappointed.

When running successful restaurant, the food must always be consistent.

The majority of the seating is upstairs.  I had wanted to take my father there, but will not because I do not think he could manage the staircase. The only options I see for downstairs seating is a patio (which would be fine in nice weather) or a couple of small tables just inside the front door where everyone checks in which doesn't look very cozy.  I'm not aware of more ample indoor seating downstairs.

I paid 50$ for breakfast and I'm not sure why. Mimosas by the pitcher were nice, but that's where it stopped. Fried potatoes were uncooked chunks. Omelette was nothing special. Pancake was good but definitely not worth 5$. Parking lot sucks. We will not be back .

Very cute brunch spot near Purdue's campus. Ate here on a Sunday morning around 10am. Was seated right away on the patio. 

I ordered a latte and my sister and I split a #1 (two eggs, home fries, and a pancake) and an extra pancake. So much food we couldn't finish, but boy was it good. The home fries were super crispy and the pancake had so much flavor we didn't even add syrup. 

Total bill came out to be around $20. Great value. I will definitely come back!

Excellent food and wonderful service for our large group of 12! Olivia (sp?) was so patient with our five year old granddaughter as well our adult daughter with autism, and even got up on a chair (safely) to take a beautiful photo of our group. This is our younger daughter's Purdue graduation weekend and we're so glad we celebrated there!

First time here visiting for Purdue graduation and looking for a brunch spot. The reviews are mixed so we tried it out. We were able to get a seat right away but they seated 3 of us at a 2 top. My guests order biscuits and gravy with fried eggs, fried eggs bacon and pancakes, I had a corned beef omelette and home fries.
The gravy "an Indiana favorite" was a brownish color instead of white which is actually an Indiana tradition. Both orders of eggs were over medium but both were cooked over easy. The omelette was pretty good but the nature of filling the eggs rather than cooking the ingredients with the eggs left it a bit flavorless even with the addition of hollandaise. 
Servers all had stained untucked shirts which seemed a bit odd as a uniform.

This is my 3rd time at this restaurant for brunch. The quality of the food has been hit and miss, ranging from "not bad to mediocre". The reason for my visits were because there aren't that many brunch place near by campus. My major complain is the high price, typically $35-40 with order of two plates and soda/coffee drinks. 

Today, we ordered tax mex omelet and salmon croissant bennie. The food quality simply was not good enough for the price. The omelet's ingredient was sandwiched (not well mixed) meaning that all the spinach was jammed in the lower corner and each ingredient stacked next to each other. 

The croissant bennie was very very salty. Like I said, it's been hit and miss so far.

Town & Gown, I never got out of the car to try your food so I could write a proper review. All I did was circle around the parking lot hoping that someone would leave so I could grab their spot. I know that's a lousy reason to write a review, but I'm warning others you better have a Plan B because the parking here is terrible. We went with our Plan B. Sorry, maybe next time I can hit the parking lottery and write a real review. Until then, this is what you get.

I chose this place for the Tiramisu! I had looked through the pictures on Yelp and thought this would be great! We walked in and it was busy. The inside was nice. We should've waited for a seat upstairs. Instead they sat all 3 of us at a small round table up front by the door. I ordered the biscuits and gravy. The biscuits were good, but I don't like the brown kind of gravy. I like the standard white gravy. I didn't know it was the brown gravy if I had known I would've ordered something different. So, I ordered the tiramisu for dessert and it didn't look like what the other pictures on Yelp looked like. It looked like it was caked with chocolate sauce and cocoa powder. No, spoon imprint like the other pictures on Yelp. I've had tiramisu at other places this one had so much rum in it it wasn't good. It overpowered the entire dessert. The other food that had come out looked good and I've heard upstairs is more open and they have an open bar up there. I would try it again and order other items instead of the two I got.

reviews.text:
We had such a wonderful birthday experience at Revolution Barbeque! Lafayette can sometimes feel like it's lacking in good, solid restaurants that know what they're doing, but I can say, whole-heartedly, that Revolution Barbeque has all the knowledge.

We sat-in the restaurant, despite their booming carry out service, and enjoyed our time with all of the other patrons. For a Thursday night, they were surprisingly busy! There is a main dining area and then a craft bar area to the other side of a bricked wall. We opted for the bar area which had some dimmer lighting and a moodier ambience. We were immediately greeted by the bartender and my partner ordered a special bourbon cocktail. Whoever made their cocktail menu definitely knows what they're doing, because you'd have assumed you were in Chicago or Nashville. A bit pricey for Lafayette standards when you're staring at the menu, but just bite the bullet and order the drink, because they're well worth it. Beautiful presentation and such a nice experience. I would say Revolution Barbeque would be a nice place to come and just have a drink, but... how could you resist NOT eating something?

The food came and we were so impressed. We had actually ordered 3 sides between the two of us, however they mixed up our orders with another tables and made good by correcting our order and providing us with an overall total of 5 different sides to try out! We had the mustard greens, the Mac and cheese, the baked beans, the slaw, and the potato salad. Now, I am probably the pickiest eater under the sun, but I can tell you, whoever is cooking this food knows how to make a damn good side. The sides with the waffle corn bread were outstanding. I mean, straight out of the south. And, at a BBQ place? To rave about their sides? That's saying something. I had never had mustard greens and they were stellar and something I'd eat any day. The baked beans were out of this world. The Mac and cheese was amazing. I don't know what was in the corn bread, but I can say it's safe to say that it should be illegal, because I'm sure it's highly addictive. 

I am not a meat person at all, however the BBQ was so rich in flavor and so finely crafted. I never eat an entire sandwich and I can say I downed mine within a couple minutes. Granted, it comes with a lot of meat, so I pushed a bit to the side! Now I have leftovers for this evening's meal. 

Such a nice experience for a birthday meal and such a nice addition to downtown Lafayette. They have the sweetest and funniest staff who help you pick everything you want, and they have incredible food with great drinks and a fun environment. If I could give 10 stars, I would.

We bought takeout here for lunch on a Friday in April 2021. We bought two brisket plates and each came with two sides plus cornbread. Our four sides were sweet potato fries, mac and cheese, baked beans, and coleslaw with vinaigrette. Everything was outstanding including the cornbread that comes in the shape of a waffle. Highly recommend this place. It will be a routine stop for us.

We ordered takeout and opted for the Friday special of the day, the Smokehouse Burger. It's a burger topped with pulled pork, cheese, onion and strawberry habanero sauce. The burger had a very generous amount of toppings, and the bun was homemade. It was a great combination of flavors! We loved the sauce, tasted like strawberries on the front end and then hit you with the heat. We opted for the creamy slaw and potato salad as our sides. The slaw was crunchy and not too sweet or soupy. The potato salad had a great texture and flavor. 

Service was quick and friendly. They had my order available to pickup in 10 minutes.

This was such a great find! My husband and I love barbecue and this restaurant totally nailed it. The interior of the restaurant is absolutely gorgeous with rich, brick walls. The bar looks super cool too!
We started with Whiskey + Cherry Coke and Winter Sangria slushees, and they were amazing! Wonderful flavors and the consistency was perfect.
For dinner, we shared one of their platters -- the pulled pork, but we also added the brisket to it. We got sides of potato salad and Mac n cheese. The platter came with Texas toast as well. Everything was DELICIOUS. The brisket and pork were more traditional -- slices of brisket and roughly pulled pork, which we really liked. The Mac n cheese was also....incredible. 
The meal came with four barbecue sauces -- the mustard and strawberry jalapeño were my favorites, and my husband was happy with their original. They also had a hot barbecue option!
The bartender was our server and he was very attentive, making sure that our needs were met throughout the meal. All in all, it was a great experience!

I want to share an experience to let you know the kind of people that own this business. Out front of the bar side door is a metal plate covering a chute the goes to the basement for deliveries. In September my family chose to go to Revolution for lunch. 5 of us. As we walked, my 70 year old mother hit the plate wrong and fell in to the chute, dropping 2 feet in to the ground, and seriously bruising her arm (which was x-rayed last month and STILL has a large lump under the skin). 

The bartender cam running out, and SAW my mother in the whole. The street crew doing maintenance across the street also saw, and two pedestrians came running to help her. The bartender went to get the owner. There were 6 eye witnesses. 

The female owner came out and looked at the plate and kept saying that "she just didn't see how that could possibly happen," and kept insinuating that this was my mother's fault that their pitfall in THEIR property was not secured. I have included pictures of the plate that were taken later that week when you can see they were attempting to fix it. This was one of the days of outdoor dining downtown, and there are no cones or anything marking this hazard. 

Unbeknownst to this woman I WORKED in this same building when it was another restaurant, and it was always a concern someone would be hurt on this plate. One person had fallen in before. 

The owner went about downplaying the incident, and saying she just didn't understand, and she would need to talk to her husband. We had to FORCE HER to take our number. 

Her husband never did show up. She never owned she was at fault (even after my mother said she would never press charges because her father had owned a small business). She didn't comp the lunch (which was marginal at best), she didn't comp half the lunch, she gave us three pieces of pie and never said another word. 

They never called to express concern, or follow up. She could have sued Revolution and the city, but she didn't. Even after two injuries that could have been very serious had she completely gone down the keg chute. These are not good people. Do not give them your money. You can make BBQ just as good at home and not give a profit to unkind people.

Exquisite urban environment with lots of space and very family oriented staff. My buddy and I tried out Revolution for the first time this week and overall had decent things to say. Thankful that the prices don't take advantage but noticed that my buddy's order of ribs surprisingly made it out of the kichen, extremely fatty and lacking flavor, required a lot more digging and scraping then restaurant ribs I have become used to that rather fall off the bone with a few pokes and nibbles. Surprisingly Cheddar's comes to mind as some of the best ribs in the area. He should have ordered the pork or copied me for briscut! My 8oz was tender, nicely seasoned, soft enough, quite generous with the sides too unlike *cough* the new Ripple place nextdoor *cough* - I made the silly rookie mistake of saying beans for a side meaning the green beans but ended up with the basic beans. Would have been fine but the heavy beans along with my wonderful thick chili made for rich sides, filling n all but I'll do the slaw next time. I sampled the potato salad, rave reviews easy! The bar area is a splendid mix of classy and neat, great specialty slushies for the refined adult still trying to grow up. Of course I got the whiskey root beer! So good! Stuff of pool parties in fancy beach houses, a good size too, overall fitting well with the meats. Ended with an apple pie because they were out of banana cream (weeping), crust was very crusty and filling quite sweet, still easy to eat. Despite the weird turnout with the ribs, we both agreed we will have to come back and sample more of the menu to make sure the ribs were not just a fluke.

Finally got to try Revolution BBQ! I came here for lunch with a friend. We had both heard great things and wanted to avoid the dinner rush. I've heard they can get super busy. Atmosphere is great! Lots of space in the building. Industrial feel and cool bar area. Menu is nice, with some delicious sounding appetizers and sides. I had the brisket taco, pork BBQ taco, Mac-n-cheese, and featured lemonade. Damn. The Mac-n-cheese was spot on. Tacos were very good, but I liked the pork one the best.

Sauces are tasty, but wanted more heat. Strawberry habanero is not spicy at all. My friend had the smoked chicken sandwich, sweet potato fries, and a bourbon pecan chocolate pie to go. She enjoyed her food. They make house buns for sandwiches! Overall, awesome experience. Highly recommend.

Stopped by this cute joint for dinner.  Shared a bbq plate with two sides and extra meet and it was plenty of food for two.  The brisket was moist and flavorful.  The cornbread was a little waffle.  There were many choices of bbq sauce the origami and hot were both good.  The Mac and cheese was amazing.  They also have a beer and a shot for $5.  How can you go wrong?

Lafayette is (surprisingly) full of good food, and the barbecue is no exception at Revolution. The food here is stupid good, especially the brisket and the pulled pork. Also be sure to give their drinks a go. Excellent staff, always clean, and quick service. I highly recommend.

The restaurant closes at 9, but the bar is open till midnight. If you're still hoping for a late night bite they feature "bar snacks" in the form of Tacos from 9-Midnight on Friday & Saturday. I've never had anything from here that I haven't liked and these tacos were fantastic. I ordered two, Mexican style (with pico and cheddar cheese), they hit the spot in the Goldilocks way- not too much, not too little, juuuust right. Service was friendly, accommodating to my questions and overall this is one of the best places in downtown!

Maybe my favorite place in Downtown Lafayette. 

Great Food, $5 dollar shot and beer combo, and great staff that won't give you the cold shoulder.

Stopped in during Lafayette Fresh Air Eats. Perfect weather, Great food, price a little higher ($28 for two sandwiches + drinks) but was justified by the quality of the food.  The portions of brisket and pulled pork were generous, and the sides of mustard greens and sweet potato fries were ample.  The meats were some of the best barbecue Lafayette has to offer, in my experience.  

I hope this place is around for a long time!

We went for a late lunch today and we were not disappointed! The restaurant was very spacious and clean. The girl working the counter was able to answer all our questions and made recommendations. The food was very good and full of flavor. There are several different bbq sauces to choose from. I can't wait to go back!

Sampled an assortment of sides with brisket. The brisket had big portions but seemed to be pretty fatty. All the sides were hearty and tasty. They were out of grits which I'd love to try! Another customer also recommended their tacos as best on their menu. It was extremely busy so takeout was 20+ minutes late. They did give out free bakery items for those waiting. Just order early for takeout :)

Just enjoyed another great meal at Revolution. We ordered the brisket and ribs.  Perfectly cooked.  All the sides we chose great as well. On our weekday schedule now.  Recommend highly.  Service is always good

We enjoyed our time here last night.  We sat outside and enjoyed the great weather while drinking their homemade strawberry lemonades.  Their brisket was delicious! You can pick a few different sauces with your meal-I tried their original bbq and peach mustard, both were sweeter than I expected but still yummy.  Their baked beans, potato salad, Mac n cheese, and homemade pickles were also great.  We will definitely be back!

Delicious food. Try the Duck!! Everything was perfect. Service was exceptional, and I would recommend this place for any smokehouse bbq expert--very family-friendly and a great selection of spirits. The Conguito Slushi is delicious.

More like 3.5! The food definitely wasn't bad by any means, just not really what I expect from a barbeque spot. (I'm from the Carolinas for reference) I do super appreciate the addition of outdoor seating and will almost certainly return to the bar once COVID dies down.
The smoked chicken was pretty good. Only complaint is that the house bbq sauce tasted extremely strongly of cumin? It wasn't like any bbq sauce I've ever had before.
The mustard greens were gritty. You really have to wash those suckers.
The cornbread was surprisingly good. It was definitely the best thing on my plate.

The service was excellent. Unfortunately the food wasn't. The place had come highly recommended. The pulled pork was almost entirely fat. The brisket was dry. Although it had good flavor and the bbq sauce was great. The highlight was the S'mores pie for dessert which shouldn't be the highlight for a BBQ joint. $45 for one meal, 2 soft drinks and 2 Desserts was a not a good value for mediocre food. I might try again but my wife won't.

Tonight my family are at Revolution barbecue and enjoyed every part of the experience. Their loaded tots were fresh and delicious, as were their house fried pickles. We tried each meat that was served in a taco and was thoroughly impressed by how fresh and delicious they tasted. We also had a blackberry chocolate pie and a salted caramel chocolate pie. Both were the perfect amount of sweetness and richness. We. And wait to come back and enjoy more of theirs fabulous entrees.

reviews.text: Loved that we were able to sign up for a table remotely via Yelp. We were then able to check in upon arrival and waited a few minutes to get seated. As first time guests we got the beignets half off and they were AMAZING. We had the eggs Blackstone benedict, cinnamon roll French toast which came with side of eggs and the southwest omelet. This was a great balance of sweet and flavory for 2 people ( maybe too much). Will be visiting again for outdoor seating now that the weather is nice.

We had breakfast here before a Purdue tour today. It was awesome all the way around. The staff was efficient, knowledgeable, and super friendly. They are doing a good job following COVID protocols. The best part is the food. They have so many good choices it was hard to choose! We started with a plate of the bomb complimentary beignets and awesome coffee. Our table had the Southwestern Scramble without the andouille, the Croissant French Toast, the Cinnamon Roll French Toast and the Salmon Bowl. Everything was fresh and amazing! We were a little rushed so our server packed up part of it to go. She was incredibly accommodating. Really enjoyed this meal. I would highly recommend it!

All I can say is wow. After 4 years of attending Purdue, I decided to try Another Broken Egg Cafe and was extremely impressed.

Positives

-Food: The food is incredible with flavors and combinations that you really can't get anywhere else. The vibe is Cajun with many of the dishes having crawfish, anduille, shrimp, etc, but they also have traditional fares for anyone. The chefs really put craft into their dishes.

-Service: It's tough to get a table on the weekends, but the staff is super nice. Our waitress was very accommodating, kept refills coming promptly, and aided in our questions on the menu.

-Drinks: They have really good coffee, brunch cocktails, and specialty coffee/sweet drinks for anyone to enjoy.

Negatives

-Price: While the food is quite good, the price is pretty steep for most college students or really anyone getting brunch/breakfast. Most dishes are 12-18$, coffee 3.50$, and specialty drink 5+$ vs the typical 6-10$ fares at many diners around. The ingredients reflect the price, but usually that spend is reserved for nicer dinners for most people.

I ordered the lobster and brie omelette with an English muffin and fresh country potatoes. The omelette was okay. It was pretty bland and unimpressive. The omelette tasted a lot more fishy than I was expecting. The potatoes were pretty good. My meal was really big and kept me full for several hours. Also, we were seated closer to other diners than I would have liked. I believe that guests should have been more spaced out to promote safety.

First timing visiting this brunch joint on Purdue Campus.   Each of us enjoyed our entrees.  Belgian waffle cooked perfectly (better with melted butter).   My breakfast sandwich of fried chicken covered in sausage gravy was delicious.  My wife ordered the  crab cakes and fried green tomato entree.  I am guessing it was great since I was not offered a bite

Would recommend to anyone visiting the campus.

My husband, daughter, and I toured Purdue this morning for an hour and we were pretty darned hungry afterwards. My daughter wanted to stay on or close to campus so she suggested Another Broken Egg. I'll confess that I had already selected another restaurant in West Lafayette and had even selected my beverage snd entree so I was silently disappointed. We walked in and was immediately greeted by a friendly hostess and seated. Our waitress, Cheyenne, was great. She suggested many of the house favorites. I settled on the seasonal corned beef, Brussels, and blistered tomatoes topped with two over easy eggs. My was I surprised how good my meal was! The eggs were perfectly cooked with crispy edges. The yolk blended beautifully with the corned beef, potatoes, and veggies. There was a dollop of sour cream that brought all together so well. My husband had the chicken fried steak Benedict, which he said was good and my daughter had the salmon Benedict that she said was good but had a tad too much seasoning salt. Over all we had a great breakfast that did not disappoint.

Have come here years before and have to say that the quality of food and service has declined since then. Ordered a black coffee and asked for non dairy milk and was given coconut cream.... um how does a restaurant in this age still not carry non dairy milk? Just source it from a grocery store it's like a 5 minute drive. We ordered no eggs and just sausage for a side and was given eggs with bacon ... I don't understand if these waitresses can't hear or what but coconut cream is not milk and no eggs does not mean eggs. Anyways, the portions are ridiculously ginormous so better not eat for some time prior to coming unless you wanna waste half a meal.
Stopped in for breakfast and had the Floridian omlet. It was good sized and came with grits. Nice and friendly people but a bit hard to find.

This place wasn't what I expected. From their images online I was hoping for the best and some delicious food. They were very busy which I expected on a Sunday so I did use the Yelp app to reserve a spot in line which was awesome and they sat us down almost immediately. My server seemed very unknowledgeable about the menu and what it offered. I asked if they did any flavored iced coffees and she said she wasn't sure and she'd check. She just brought me a very iced down coffee with little flavor that I wasn't thrilled about. Gave her the benefit of the doubt, maybe she's new and that's fine. I ordered the eggs Benedict and my mom had an omelet. The food came and while it looked amazing the taste just wasn't.. my eggs were cold and the flavors were just okay. My mom said her omelet seemed very over done and wasn't too happy either. My favorite part was the complimentary pancake beignets. Those were soft, hot and yummy but we didn't get them until after paying for our bill. 

While I didn't enjoy this first time experience, I do think it was just a busy day and maybe I didn't order the best they had to offer. I would still come back and try something new maybe sometime.

Located in an odd spot and indifferent about the wait, it was a pleasant surprise.

With a modern and clean interior we were greeted by an eager and friendly staff. Everyone was very pleasant to work with.

We ordered the lobster Brie and cheese omelet and broken egg biscuit sandwich. Both plates were generous and filling. The omelet was extremely rich. It was savory and very decadent with the Brie, cream cheese and loads of lobster. Accompanying it was a generous cup of fresh fruit. The sandwich wasn't a pick up and eat lunch, rather neat but eaten best with a fork and to really indulge, order it with an extra side of gravy! The sandwich was an over size biscuit with a chicken tender on it covered it n Country gravy! Oh buddy, this is Nirvana after a day tailgating if you know what I mean!   ;  ) 

The coffee was a hearty cup. Not the lightweight wussy stuff watered down by so many places. It is hyper sized on the caffeine. 

The only negative is that the wait is sooo long when smelling what is cooking. My advice is if you are reading this on yelp, put your name on the list in advance and reduce your wait time, it's worth both the wait and the food!

I've been excited to try this place for a long time. The location is a little strange and I can see how parking would be a mess on game days or weekends. It's a pretty small restaurant.

Service was excellent. I had the eggs Benedict which was perfect. The eggs were just right and the ham was great. I got a fruit cup instead of potatoes which was $2.50 more. Seemed high to me, including the fact that they sell orange juice for $4 a glass! That's literally insane. I also ordered a side of "biscuits and gravy". I put it in quotes because the gravy was straight weird. It tasted like a chive party in my mouth. The biscuits were fluffy, but that gravy was just wrong. I took it to work and gave it to a coworker. My friend ordered the pound cake French toast with eggs and sausage. She was really happy with it, as well as the banana fosters syrup. She did not like the sausage. It had greens of some kind (probably chives) in it. 

For a $25 breakfast, I just thought it was OK.

Summary: Food seems a little hit-and-miss; great service.

My first time at Another Broken Egg Cafe. Came here with my husband on a Sunday around mid-morning for brunch. The wait was about 30 minutes long and we were seated at one of the high tables. 

I decided to try out one of their seasonal specials (Southern Benedict with potatoes) as they were going to be taking this off the menu shortly. My husband got the Chilaquiles. 

I can't recommend the Southern Benedict. The biscuit was dry and really bland, one poached egg was done well but the other was overcooked. The sausage was really good but there was way too much ham (that too very salty!) to really appreciate the flavours of the dish. The side of potatoes was pretty average, couldn't really taste any seasoning. Overall a pretty disappointing dish. We did inform our waitress about the salty ham and she took our feedback very well.  

The chilaquiles on the other hand was definitely better. Well garnished. I thought it was a little meat-heavy but some people may really enjoy this. 

Coffee: Not the greatest. And was lukewarm when served.  

Because it was my first time we got treated with their classic sugar dusted beignets which were an absolute delight! 

Would I go back? Yes, to try out their other dishes before settling on a final verdict.

Yes! YES! YEEEAAAASSSSSS!!!!!

Before reviewing the food let me tell you this was the best breakfast / brunch experience since Ruby Slipper in my home state of Louisiana, that's in New Orleans. 

This was and is the best meal I've had before noon in 4 years! That includes my own cooking and I'm pretty damn awesome. Despite being a franchise whomever is training and implementing the hospitality is spot on SOUTHERN CHARM. Friendly and not just our waitress Cheyenne, the Manager Seth and every single employee I saw was smiling and being friendly. Only one waitress complaining about a table that had been finished with their meal for quite some time. I get it though, these folks make their money turning tables. Let me explain what this joint gets that others miss...the second, third and fourth visits that end up making you willing to wait 45 minutes for the best experience in the area. I will and gladly.

So on this occasion we used the yelp waiting list function for the first time. Wait estimate was 22 min and it took us about 20 minutes to arrive from the east side. We arrived and within a few minutes of arriving were sent a text and seated. 

Let me be honest, I wanted to hate it on the drive there. Another knock off want to be NOLA restaurant claiming southern cuisine. "Flashback" walking up to the hostess I heard chubby checker (my moms favorite), and in front of me was a hutch that my grandmother had; I scowled. 

Here we are looking over the menu, which I was delighted was not the same paper menu that we first grabbed on arrival. I simply decided to choose my normal routine, first visit breakfast. Here is was the supreme omelette, which as offered was what I was raised on. Eggs, sausage, bacon, onions, mushrooms and Colby jack (gods omelette cheese). I added a 1/2 biscuit and gravy as well as grits. J had the chicken and waffles with home fries. 

Drinks arrive and the Bloody Mary needed some pepper and a splash of pepper sauce to meet my perfectionist standards. J orders a strawberry mimosa because I neglected to inform her that we were drinking early. Both perfect as well as the strong coffee that I sipped.

Food arrives and NEWS FLASH; we had to add seasoning to nothing!!!! 

First time visitor gets some perks (this is the well placed hook) FREE biscuit beignets arrive and I was skeptical despite J trying and loving them. They are different but delicious and if you omit the orange marmalade then you are void of taste buds.  

The freaking omelette, my mèmè would have loved this. The biscuits and sausage gravy!?!? Tender fresh biscuits with amazing sausage gravy (best in Indiana).  The grits were a little bouisey (diced tomatoes green onions and bacon). I pushed that aside for grits only... OMG perfect. Second bite with the bouisey topping; eye rolling and delightful. English Muffin with a light smear of butter to sop up lost bits and it, too was perfect.

Speaking for J as she ate some of mine as usual!!  I tried her Chicken and Waffles with Chipotle Honey on the side. It was her first chicken and waffles and she asked me how to eat it and I offered my opinion which was a fail. So the chipotle honey is a strong honey with slight chipotle kick. Independent of the sauce, she loved it. 

The honest final comment is everything on the menu speaks to my southern soul and if you find yourself trapped in Lafayette, Indiana, you should make your way to this place and piss us all off because the seating is perfect but there is already a wait! 

BTW, the music and ambiance was great the entire meal!
The place was full of people with less protection. I wouldn't go there and do a dine in. The food wasn't as good as before. Disappointed and might not go again.

tldr: The food here is solid/fine, like you'd expect at a breakfast diner. But the prices are more like restaurant level rather than cheap diner level. The result is a fairly satisfying breakfast for more money than I'd expect to spend.

My girlfriend and I shared a plate of plain French toast, which was not great (not hot, rubbery). We also shared a seafood omelette, which was good (lots of shrimp, pretty big, sauce on top). This came with an English muffin (like the French toast, not hot), a small bowl of grits (fine, plain), and a piece of ham (nice flavor). We were supposed to get a side of bacon too but only got one strip. Weird? She also got coffee and we spent $35 with tip. So again it's not like the food was bad, but it was just okay for that much money.

They do have a nice feature on the menu of writing how many calories each dish has.
This is helpful for portion control!

We went on a Saturday morning around 9am and it was not busy (we were seated right away). By 10 or so it got a bit crowded.
Loved it, always delicious! We had a chance to stop there for breakfast today, always the go-to.

This is a cute little breakfast place adjacent to the Purdue campus (located, conveniently, across the street from the Armstrong Building). It's busy for brunch, so there is a wait to get seated, but otherwise service is friendly and speedy. My server,  Brianna, was very nice and had great timing. They definitely earn their tips here! I got a Cranberry Mimosa, which was tart and tasty and perfect for the humid and rainy morning. I ordered Shrimp and Grits for my meal-it's a southern themed restaurant. The actual grits themselves are plain and overly bland, but a good texture. The accompanying sauce and baby shrimp/ sausage add the perfect amount of spice, and the garlic bread pancake things on the side are buttery and tasty. Worth the wait!

During a wonderful weekend on campus, other than a saddening loss to Michigan at sold-out Mackey Arena, my Boiler and I discovered the very best breakfast spot in West Lafayette. Admittedly this is a low bar, as breakfast sucks pretty much everywhere. We are breakfast connoisseurs, and heretofore we have found nothing but mediocrity. No more.

It's called "Another Broken Egg Cafe" and its on Northwestern Avenue, across from the Physics building. The crowds are deserved and the prices (no student budget here) well-earned. If you arrive after 9A on a weekend morning, prepare to wait for a table. And that was before this posting.

An absolute delight when it comes to breakfast and brunch classics. I went here for the first time this morning, and the interior instantly charmed me, with its red walls and modern decour, and the waitresses were the most friendly I have ever come across anywhere so far. I was asked if I had ever been there before, strangely, but I was soon enlightened that new customers got a free half-order of their mini-beignets, which further reinforced my good first impression. Beignets are hard to find anywhere outside of the south, and while their mini ones didn't quite stack up to a full-sized beignet, they were delicious nonetheless (though hard to eat neatly with a beard and black clothing, on account of the powdered sugar).

It was hard choosing what I wanted from their posh and delectable-sounding items, like bananas foster pancakes, chocolate-ganache stuffed waffles, sweet potato waffle, lemon blueberry goat cheese pancakes, cinnamon roll french toast, lobster and brie omelette, chicken and waffles -- on and on. I decided to be adventurous with the unique "crab cake benedict," though, described as jumbo crab cakes served on an English muffin, topped with poached eggs, an "Andouille-infused" hollandaise sauce, and served with a side of potatos or grits. I don't often associate fish (except for smoked salmon) with breakfast, and crab cakes are always a risky business anyways (you can either be served a very good one, or else one that gives you the runs six hours later because of food poisoning). 

Fortunately, there was no fishy business -- the crab cake was tender and went surprisingly well with the poached egg and hollandaise sauce (which had actual Andouille sausage in it, far from just being "infused"). The potatoes were acceptable -- a little dry, and my only gripe was that there was ~$1.30 charge extra for them putting cheese and bacon bits on them, which was not made known to me when it was offered while ordering. I'd say you should probably go for the grits instead. At any rate, I will certainly be returning, and hopefully I will have just as excellent an experience as I explore their other options.

The food was disappointing, but the service was decent. 

I ordered take out during my lunch and was extremely pleased with how fast I received my food. The actual food however was very disappointing. I ordered the Floridian Omelet with potatoes and English muffin. The omelets flavor seemed to get worse with each bite. The combination of crab and cheese just didn't seem to work together in flavors, at least for me. There was also just a huge glob of cream cheese in the middle. So big that it was room temp at best while the rest of the omelet was hot. I tried to eat it all because It's the most expensive omelet I have ever bought, I just couldn't manage it.  My photos are how far I got. The omelet was big and the egg part of it was wonderful the flavors just didn't seem to go together.

I was extremely disappointed in the omelet. The potatoes and English muffin were good but I didn't receive any condiments for them (I should have thought to ask)

I wouldn't suggest to anyone I know to eat here but I also wouldn't caution them away. For the price and other reviews I have read I was expecting some amazing food but was sadly disappointed.
