reviews.text:
Wife and I went here with her family, after hearing that they have one of the best tenderloin sandwiches in and around Lafayette. That definitely rang true. The meat was appropriately thick and the breading was the right "weight" -- not too light, not too heavy. More critically, it wasn't soggy or overly oily. The sandwich itself is massive. We split it between the two of us and were full. I'd strongly recommend adding their bistro sauce to the tenderloin.

Additionally, we also got the fried green beans and buffalo chips. Both were pretty good, although I'd personally get the green beans over the chips.

Overall, this is totally worth the (short) drive from Lafayette.

Don't let looks fool you, this place was great! We were greeted right as we walked in the door by our exceptional waitress. I ordered the HUGE breaded tenderloin and buffalo chips. The prices are great! My only comment would be the buffalo chips don't really have any "buffalo" flavor to them, but I still enjoyed them! Pretty much just french fries cut a little thicker than chips. I can't wait to come back and try a dinner meal. Great little place!
Can't go wrong with TCs. Small town restaurant with a small town feel.  Food is excellent.

A nice find in a very small town!  I had the catfish fillets with steak fries - all served hot and fresh!  He had the pork fillet with sweet potato fries - the pork was just perfect, thick and moist and perfectly cooked.  
We were just stopping nearby for the night and would certainly return when in this area.

Thanks to Yelp, we have found ourselves in yet ANOTHER amazingly delicious  gastro experience!  Nothing fancy but MY GOODNESS! the options are diverse and cover the likes at everyone at our table.  For fun we tried the Wasabi Crab/Shrimp Balls.  Although these are not made from scratch, they are DELICIOUS!  WOW!  These lunch options are FANTASTIC!!!!  Everything has a fantastic flavor and the presentation is beautiful. Our server told us that the restaurant has been here for 30 years and is a local favorite...I CAN TOTALLY UNDERSTAND!!!  This was a marvelous find!!!!
My family and I love to eat here. Good classic American food at a reasonable price. Service is excellent as well!

Nothing fancy.  Best Filet you can get anywhere in the area.  We choose TCs instead of going in town foe a steak.  Prime Rib night is amazing.  Craig the bartender is a riot.  Good experience each and every time.

This an unassuming mom and pop restaurant off the beaten path with lots of local atmosphere. High school memorabilia hangs on the wall from the owners, a local couple. We were there after a Purdue game and it was clear this was a "place to be" for those in the know (this place is not exactly close to the stadium). 

TC's is a "common ground" meeting place for folks of all kinds - we saw young hipster foodies and old-timer regulars; a group of guys kicking back with some beers and a girls-night-out birthday party in heels and high makeup;  an alternative couple with tattoos and piercings, and a buttoned-down family with young kids. Everyone was just there to enjoy the food and the place. 

The best thing: These folks know how to season and cook a steak! We had the strip and the filet, each medium rare. The strip was miraculously medium rare from within a millimeter of the seared edge all the way through. Unbelievable. Maybe the best steak this seasoned steak eater has had any where, any time. The filet was super flavorful, also right to temperature. Not the most velvety I've ever had, but definitely the most flavorful. Also very much recommended: the sauteed mushrooms!

The wine selection is limited but we found something we liked. Our one critique seems to be common around here where there is an apparent preference for corn-fed beef, which we struggle to understand as well-aged Western beef fans. In the end it's a small matter - especially since these folks really know how to cook a steak!

The atmosphere is very basic and old bar style. The food is delicious! I had a great cocktail, grilled tenderloin and coleslaw. My bill was less than $11. Don't miss this classic stop! Great food. Specials daily for $6.50. Yesterday was the ribs, which came with a small portion, two sides and bread. What a steal!

Visited on 10/11/18 and I think it was the best meal I've had in the years I've been coming here with my girlfriends. One thing to know about Thursday nights here - you will need a reservation. Yes, this small town restaurant is PACKED on Thursday nights, which happens to be the only night prime rib is on the menu. Interior and exterior aren't fancy, which can be misleading about the yummy food served inside! Tbh I've only had two menu items in the years I've been visiting - the pork chop and the prime rib. Both are absolutely delicious. Now the rolls and salad are ordinary but the berries are fantastic! If you still haven't been to TC's you're missing out!

What a wonderful place! First, we were really warmly greeted by our server. And that level of service just continued. There are clearly a lot of regulars, and t
I can see why. One side is more of a bar, and the other side a restaurant, but they are both open and there are tables on both sides.
Now for the food. This is a steak and sandwiches kind of place. I got the grilled cheese with buffalo chips and coleslaw. Oh those buffalo chips! I split them with hubs and they were delicious. I'd definitely get the grilled cheese again. Everyone else loved their food too, which ranged from chicken to steak with fries) and the cheese curds and onion rings were tasty and the perfect amount for 4 hungry adults and a picky teenager.
We enjoyed our meals and the service so much that we started thinking of other things to do in this area so we can all eat here again!

Great spot for lunch or dinner. In downtown Battle Ground but somewhat hidden. A favorite of locals (place was largely full for weekday lunch at 11:15). Very good specials and comfort food (great tenderloin sandwich and Pork Manhattan). Reasonable prices. Nice bar. About 10 minutes off I-65; pleasant drive through Prophetstown State Park. Tippecanoe Battlefield nearby.

My family had a mini-vacation to Indiana Beach and before we went home, we stopped by Tippecanoe Battlefield Museum. My wife looked on On Yelp for a place to have lunch and came across TC's. Caroline was our server (and she was beyond excellent) and every single expectation for a family of 5 to get a decent lunch was far exceeded... The food was delicious, the restaurant was neat and clean and we received quite possibly the best service we have ever received at ANY restaurant (high-end or otherwise). I'd like to brag again on Caroline and say that I wish every business had team members like her. She made us feel completely at home, did more for us than any server we've ever had had done and had a genuine smile on her face the entire time. Listening to her and the other staff interact with the other guests assured us that this wasn't an isolated incident... this is a TC way of life. Thanks for everything!

This is a great classic place to take the family. TC's has amazing food and a wonderful atmosphere. You cannot go wrong with anything on the menu. Just be sure to make a reservation! The place fills up fast on the weekend!

A co-worker and I stopped here on a trip up to the Prophetstown area for work. It was recommended to us by a local and it did not disappoint. 

We tried both the breaded tenderloin and the BLT. The tenderloin was huge! It had a nice balance to sandwich. It was not chewy or overly moist, but just the right amount of both. My coworker got the side salad and it was your standard side salad. 

The BLT was very tasty and had a good proportion of ingredients. The bacon was crispy and on the thicker side. I really liked the buffalo chips, which were like flattened Arby's curly fries in their flavoring and they had a good crunch to them.

The place was packed when we got in there for a late lunch. It seemed like somewhere the locals hang out a lot. Good place if you are every in the Battleground, IN area. 

They have a daily special that is $6.50 and it seemed like everyone but us was getting the chicken and noodles that are the Wednesday special.

The restaurant does not cater to children with food allergies.  We always have to bring in food for our son who is highly allergic to milk and peanuts. Whenever it is possible for us to order food for him (such as French fries as we did for him on our visit) we always will order something. As we tried to supplement his dinner with food we brought, we were immediately told we could not bring in outside food. I explained about food allergies and that I could provide a doctor's note and that was not sufficient. We were with a large group so we finished eating and I "snuck" food to our son. The rest of the groups food was fine (average, not great). Unfortunately, we will not be back....

I happened on this place totally by chance. I was lost and cruising the Indiana countryside on a trip back from Chicago.  I hit this little country restaurant and bar about 4 PM on a weekday, with already 30 or 40 cars in the parking lot.  

More out of curiosity than hunger or thirst, I stopped in to see what the fuss was about. Before I knew it, I was watching these gargantuan meals come out of the kitchen from my barstool perch: huge steaks, massive cheeseburgers, even massive salads, accompanied by a LOT of smiles when the plates were laid down. 

I ordered a fried pork tenderloin sandwich, an Indiana state dish if there ever was one. What came out was a tenderloin the size of my plate (see photo). And my plate was a full dinner plate, which was completely covered by the Paul Bunyan-esque sandwich. 

Now that I'm reading the other reviews of TC's, it's clear that all their food is oversized, well-prepared and relatively inexpensive.  By the time I left at 530, the place was jammed up, completely packed, and loaded with laughter and good conversation. 

I'm going back to this little gem of a throwback Indiana pub and restaurant on my next trip to Chicago, and I'll make sure to order a steak or a cheeseburger, which looked good, as did everything else.  And Craig the burly bartender will remember me, as he was duly impressed that I ate every single morsel of my Andre the Giant Tenderloin. And a small plate of shrooms.

Don't let this places look fool you. Steaks are great, burgers are great, and did I mention the steaks? This place is a diamond in the rough. You have to come here and try the NY strip and cheeseburger. I promise you will not be disappointed.

Stopped in with my brother one afternoon and the waitress was the nicest woman! She greeted us by name and made sure we had full drinks, brought our food out promptly, and was more than happy to be working which made the environment enjoyable. The hand-breaded tenderloin sandwich is hands down the best in Indiana!! Best kept secret for tenderloins in Indiana!

I've never had a bad meal here. I've always gone with the 10oz filet and Buffalo chips. The past 2 times I went with the tenderloin. The tenderloin is big enough for 2 meals every time. This is also the fist place I've ever seen my wife eat steak! It's a hole in the wall place and a relaxed fun atmosphere. The kitchen closes at 9 p.m.  Be sure to make reservation to get a seat, if not you may not get in or you'll wait a long time. I'd recommend it to anyone in town or visiting from out of town!

reviews.text:
This was my first visit to a Lotsa which I really enjoyed.  The facility is very clean, large, socially distanced, open and white!  The subway tile in the wall really brightens the restaurant.

Upon coming in the facility you have to figure out where to go.  It's not obvious.  One you get funneled down the shoot...you get to the kiosk to enter tour order.  The menu is simple.  The order entry process was actually pretty easy.  There was only two staff in the restaurant at the time.  One was focused on making food.  The order caller was very friendly and helpful.

For dinner we ordered several items.  The Apple Pie wings were outstanding.  The wings were very moist.  They weren't very large and there were only 6 wings for $8. The BBQ sauce was nice...not overpowering but added a nice taste without being dripping wet.

The Caesar salad pizza was very innovative.  The Caesar salad was fresh.  The dressing was much like you expect.  The amount was just right to give the salad taste without ruining it.  The cheesy bread underneath was outstanding.  The bread was soft and the cheese was delicious!

The Caprita pizza was also delicious.  The tomato sauce was light with a slightly spicy taste.  It had a mild tomato taste that was much more mild than a normal marinara sauce.  The toppings very light but fresh and tasty.  The balsamic glaze was strong in taste but had a wonderful accept to the cheese, sauce and veggies.

I was disappointed that the fountain soda machine was out of service.  They gave me a bottled Diet Coke from the cooler. I had to ask for a cup and ice because the bottle was warm..and the soda was very flat.

Overall...I really liked Lotsa.  Give it a try!

Pizza on Purdue's campus is absolutely nothing to write home about. Sure, I'm an IU grad so I'm biased but outside of Mad Mushroom, you really don't have options. At all. So when my friend and I visited 2 years after gradating, we were amazed to se an addition to West Lafayette in Lotsa Pizza.

The name might need help, but the pizza definitely doesn't. While we had our sights set on a food tour, we knew we wanted pizza so we kept it light, splitting one pizza to save room for dessert. I have a policy with new places- KISS. Never experiment, and always veer towards a margherita-esque option to judge fairly. The same rules applied here.

Current Boilermakers are pampered with this pizza: with a wood-fired crust that reminds me of MOD in Indianapolis, this pizza is the veritable opposite of the Merriam-Webster definition of 'college pizza.' It's well-crafted, unique, balanced, and NOT over-indulgent.

Sure, it won't cut it when you're hungover, but that's what Mad Mush cheesestix are for. This is a pizza you can build into your life in regular intervals and proportions without risking the Freshmen 15.
Awesome. Great value for the price. My Herbivore pizza was delicious and so was the house salad. Simple. Excellent.
Decent campus fare. The personal pizzas here are square and the cheese carmelizes near the crust. A bit greasy. The bread is fluffy, though.

It's alright. It is reasonably priced for what you get, but what you get isn't ideal. The edges are very crispy, but the bottom was not. It was barley browning and very gummy. The crust was not cooked all the way through. What was cooked through was nice.

Gluten Free Review: 

I was pleasantly surprised that when ordering I was asked whether my gluten free order was due to preference or allergy.  Without being asked or prompted, staff changed gloves and scrubbed the oven before baking my pizza by itself in the rotating oven.  They use Udi's crust, if you are curious.  
I had the Bianca, and loved it.  Lots of cheese, and the crust was not too cracker-like.   Actually could bend it like good New York pizza.  Flavor was excellent.  I had mine finished with salt and fresh basil.  
Drinks are serve yourself, from one of those Coke choose your own adventure kind.  

Atmosphere is what you would expect from a college town.  Not fancy, but serviceable.  All sizes of tables to accommodate all party sizes:   Not too loud, even on a Saturday after the game.   I would like salt and pepper and parrmesan at the tables it's understandable that they would probably walk home with some student, so it's forgivable.  Staff was courteous and efficient.

So I ordered my pizza off DoorDash. It got here and it's super yummy, but it's missing the chicken and basil I ordered on it. 
I'll still eat it, but I'm sad it's  not what I ordered.

For my recent birthday, I chose Lotsa Pizza so that my family could select their own pizzas and know that they are safe since Lotsa offers gluten-free crusts. (The four of us all have Celiac Disease.)

Boy was I wrong.

The wait to order our pizza was long even though there were not that many people in line. The employees seemed overmatched. But that was not the worst part of our experience.

I made it clear to the employee taking our order that all four us were gluten-free due to allergy. For some reason, he only wrote Allergy on three of the sheets that accompany the pies. He made my older son's pizza on regular crust.

Fortunately, the guy who puts the pies in the oven discovered the error and they remade the pizza. However, that was not communicated to us and when I went back to ask what was being done, I was completely ignored even though I was two feet away and politely saying, "Excuse me" to get his attention. Finally, another employee had the courage to make eye contact and assured me that he was remaking the pizza.

Still because of the time to remake the pizza, other pizzas with gluten crusts were put in the oven. That potential cross-contamination could be the reason that my son felt sick after eating.

Lotsa reasons to never return to this place.

Edit: Since I cannot reply directly to the owner's comment, I will do do here. No, sir, I do not want your offer of free pizza. Your employees made two of my family members sick because of negligence. As I said, we will not be back.

Yummy build your own pizza. The crust is perfect mix between crisp and chewy. 

Some confusion on getting the names mixed up- but other than that decent service.

We were in town for a local baseball game.  After the rain out, we headed out to try LSFP.  Having never been there, I was a bit intimidated as the instructions were not clear.  However, the staff was friendly and helpful.

We purchased a couple build your own pizzas and they were done quick.  I added some pesto sauce to mine and it was great.

I like that they have vegan cheese options, as my daughter has cheese allergies.  We will be back with her when we are in town next.

We stopped in Sunday 6:45p and ordered 2 pizzas. I made sure that I wanted both well done. Mentioned it twice. Didn't happen. Disappointed. The  man working the register and toppings and oven was overwhelmed. He was trying. The papers under pies had well done wrote on. 
There was a line of customers with only 3 employees . He got confused trying to sort another order.  That rotating stone is part of the issue. 35 years ago I had my own parlor. We had Blodgett ovens set at 425. with slate Never seen  this type.  The problem is management understaffing.  Food was tasty. Need to ID pies in oven. Just a suggestion.

Disappointed in this. Ordered a make your own with pepperoni, sausage, and a few toppings. Standard red sauce, cheese, and crust. I picked up a piece and it was really floppy, which I passed off at first. Tried eating it was a fork but it was impossible because the pieces would just stretch like glue. I uploaded two photos to better show. The pile you see at the top is an entire piece + crust included - not just the toppings. The second picture is trying to hold a piece up to show how flimsy it is. The top cheese is hardly melted and the pepperoni looks like it just came out of the package..so I'm wondering if it's even fully cooked. Completely disappointed.

Went in here on a Tuesday for lunch and I've gotta say that I enjoyed the experience. I was feeling a bit adventurous and so, got the lunch special for the day - the Bianca for $5.99. Now that is a pretty good deal for their pizzas. The location is fantastic, service was great, price was decent and the pizzas themselves tasted pretty good. I really liked the crust. That being said, I was initially charged full price even though I asked for the lunch special and I had to ask for it to get changed. I'll be going back for their pizzas, though.

I've been here half a dozen times and it's always good. Pizza of your choice, nice staff, fresh ingredients, clean seating area, etc... The crust is thin but firm, and the edges slightly chewy. Spot on. Lotsa has the fancy Coca-Cola machine and I'm a sucker for vanilla Diet Coke. Lotsa stands above the rest in a crowded pizza market. For me it's a favorite go-to lunch in general. The daily special is a great deal: pizza of the day and drink for ~$8.50.
Love their ranch. Cheap good pizza if you like different type of topping compared to the basic ones.

Lotsa failure. Ordered two pizzas online, to be ready in 20 minutes. Arrived at the 20 minutes-later mark only to see people who arrived AFTER us place their orders and receive their pizzas before us. Frustrating. A few employees had moments when they could have been throwing ready-made pizzas into the oven but did not. Didn't even have our garlic sticks ready another 20 minutes later. 

Went to Mad Mushroom instead. You should do the same.

Top spot for pizza and definitely above all the cliche chains in the area. My BBQ Chicken was made in a few good minutes and the service was good enough for a college town eatery. Prices here are great, gluten free crust available, menu has original flavors, and place has plenty of space for large groups but wish there was more informative pricing on adding toppings for a custom pie. I'd like to see other sizes available too since a group having to order their own personal pizzas each gets really hassled and frustrating trying to make each person pick a topping and hope they all eat everything. That's obviously getting very picky. Only real issues are limited and awkward parking especially on busy weekends and watching the nice people try to handle the sardines (c'mon guys it's a great salty addition completely transformed in flavor when it gets on pizza.... OK might still be just for me but I'm all about that option here! few other spots in the whole city offer sardines on pizza).

I am especially pleased to see a build your own stone fire pizza chain come to the small college town of West Lafayette. No other establishment would've fit better in orange leaf's place (RIP). 

Everything was good, but if I had to pick something that limited my pizza love, then it'd be the 5 free toppings. At Blaze and Pieology, they do free unlimited toppings. Maybe lotsa will change in the future, but I mean, I guess you really shouldn't be getting more than 5 toppings (because you'll get fat like me). 

Loved it, will be coming back often.

I have been to Lotsa about three times so far, and it has always been a great experience. I love these types of places, and I'm glad to see West Lafayette finally has a good make your own pizza venue. Also, for it to be located on campus is a dream come true. 

If you've never been to one of these places before, the process is fairly simple - you pick a pizza dough, a type of sauce, your cheese, and toppings. They then fire the pizza in the oven for a few minutes. All pizzas are personal sized. Once pulled out of the oven, you can then add a finishing sauce/ingredient. (Such as olive oil, ranch, arugula, etc.)

I happen to honestly really enjoy this location. Other make your own pizza places tend to have very thin crust in my experience, but Lotsa's dough tends to have more volume and is a nice compromise between super thick crust (which would probably take longer to cook properly) and paper thin crust (which ends up tasting like a cracker). 

The selection of toppings is more than sufficient, and you can get pretty creative. I'm a big fan of Hawaiian pizzas, so I typically order red sauce with ham, pineapple, and ricotta cheese. Sometimes I do mushrooms instead. It's good no matter what! I've never found myself needing a finisher, but I may have to try the pesto someday.

It's an incredibly filling meal for the price you pay. For a make your own, prices run at $8 unless you add a premium topping such as shrimp. Compared to some of the other prices on campus, this is incredibly reasonable. If you weren't particularly hungry, and were just looking for a small bite to eat, I could even see sharing one of these between two people - it's a good amount of food.

Lotsa stays open late some nights, which is definitely nice if you're looking for a late night meal. I've only gone for lunch before, however.

The interior is clean and modern, and there is a good amount of seating. 

Overall, I am so glad to have Lotsa as an option on campus. I will definitely be returning this upcoming semester!

Visited for the first time (for lunch) on 4/4/18 and it was a good experience. Placing your order is a lot like ordering a sandwich from Subway. Positives: you can build your own pizza or salad, or you can choose from specials they've already designed. It was a surprisingly fast cook, which was appreciated since I only had an hour for lunch. The size of the pizza was a surprise too, and the variety of crusts was a plus (regular, wheat or gluten-free). They have daily specials too, which knocks a couple bucks off. Overall the flavor of the pizza sauce was good and the toppings were tasty.
Downside
I observed the person on the cash register taking customer payments and moving food around when it came out of the oven. He did not have food handling gloves on then, nor later when I was leaving. 
I would visit again to try a different type of pizza.

reviews.text:
You can't judge a book by its cover. It isn't obvious from the name that this is a sushi/Korean restaurant. And, if you drove past Purdue West you would assume that the restaurant is a casual takeout place. I had heard about a sushi place at Purdue West so I was looking for it. I was shocked to walk into a nicely decorated restaurant with table service. 

The lunch sushi rolls are named after buildings on campus and I had the Hall of Music roll (spicy crab roll) and the Stewart roll (spicy tuna) and they were both really good. They also have many Korean dishes such as bibimbap, Korean fried chicken, gamja tang, etc. Food arrived quickly so people on their lunch hour could easily have enough time for lunch.

There are weird hours during the summer, but we were able to come in for dinner on a weekday night.  It definitely looks like we should visit during lunch for the sushi roll specials! 

The sushi rolls we ordered were okay, but I have had better in the area. Some of the pieces of sashimi tasted as though it's been thawed out. I wouldn't come back for dinner, but I'd probably check out lunch.

I was pleased to find this asian themed restaurant close to Purdue's campus. I enjoyed this place for several reasons, the first being the variety in their menu. I ordered the bibimbap in a stone bowl, which allowed me to scrape the bottom for those crunchy bits of rice. However, the flavor was a bit lacking in my opinion. The complimentary miso soup was a surprise on a chilly day, and also quite tasty. I look forward to trying this place again!
Hope you guys never order to go！so awful！ I order a soup to go, when I came home and opened it. You can see the picture. What's it? Are you humiliated me??? Worst restaurants at west Lafayette‍‍‍‍‍

Takeout review:The wings here - more korean than japanese in style- are outstanding but hidden in the menu.  They're meaty, crunchy and loaded with sauce.  Better than bonchon in chicago in my opinion.

We also ordered asparagus roll, which was just right, and eel roll.  See the pic for the wings tho...

On second venture we ordered more of their lunch special rolls, dragon roll and sashimi / sushi combos.  Pics attached!

For the Purdue/West Lafayette, IN area, this place is fantastic. Very decent sushi and basic Korean food options. Service is friendly and the kitchen is efficient. Maybe drink at home, though, since the beer is a bit too expensive. Best deal is to eat here at lunch when they have bento boxes.

If you live near the west side of the Purdue campus, this is also one of the only food options in town--either this or Papa John's Pizza.

My husband and I ordered chicken teriyaki bento lunch box.This meal was really tasty and satisfying. A delicious Miso soup was also served before main meal. They also have good deal specials for lunch.

Delicious! We are from the Twin Cities and if my son chooses Purdue this will be our go to place. Enjoyed every bite: chicken wings to start perfect and wanted more, then we ordered hot tea worth it, lunch rolls number four, number five, number seven, and number 11. Also one deluxe role: treasure Island. Yes! So good.
One of my favorite asian in Purdue but they only open only on some days. I like the lunch combo, picked Stewart and Krannert roll. Their bento box is superb

One day I received a takeout menu on my car in a parking garage. I am always looking to try new sushi places in town, so I figured I would give it a try. This is by far the best sushi place I have found in town. They have a variety of unique rolls and sushi bowls. They were not overly busy when we went for dinner, but do not let that deter you as the food is wonderful. Our server was so kind and our sushi did not take long. I will be back!

The food tastes great: fresh and flavoured just right. 
Not very Japanese I must say, it is more Americanized. Still the food is pretty good. 
Service is welcoming and comforting, environment is clean. Lighting might be a bit dark, but during the day it's fine. 
Price is a bit high for the quality and portion, but it is better than most Japanese restaurants around Purdue. 
Overall worth trying, be ready to pay a bit more than you expected.

Came for lunch before noon on a weekday after class was out. People started streaming in at about 12-12:15. Was surprised. Very nice decor, comfortable seats, chic place. Good service.

I ordered a fried tofu appetizer and the sauce was delicious. Miso was also pretty good. 

My bulgogi bento was ok. Meat could have been either flavored more or cooked less. I liked the onions mixed in. The roll with it was just ok...too much rice, though. The salad was terrible. Dressing was mayo-based. Not like a normal Japanes/fusion ginger dressing. Bad. 

Wife enjoyed all three of her rolls a lot. I tried them all and thought they had too much rice or no texture. And the fish was ok, not great.

It may be one of the better Asian restaurants around campus, but there are several better ones around town and I will likely stick with those.

This is the best sushi place ever! The rolls kept getting better and better. We had the Snow White roll,Indiana roll, sexy roll, sweet Hawaiian, and the rainbow,they were all astonishing. The waitress was nice. Great atmosphere. Pretty awesome over all. Definitely recommend!

My husband and I just moved from Okinawa, Japan. My husband is now a soccer coach with Fishya, a Korean and Japanese restaurant, sponsoring the team. We had a table of 7. Fastest service I have ever had at a restaurant that wasn't fast food. 

We ordered the bulgogi (spicy of course), Ramen (which we requested to also be spicy), Gyoza, California roll, and my favorite the Dragon Roll. Eel is my absolute favorite sushi. The ramen was different than what I am used to in Japan. There was corn in it which gave it a distinct flavor. 
My husband said Yummytime has better bulgogi per meat and juiciness ratio.
But for sushi. Hands down the absolute best I have had so far since moving here. I will come back when I am craving sushi.  I shared with my 6 year old son and we wanted more! 

We are truly lucky to live next to Purdue, where different cultures collide, and we can have a little taste from our home we had in Japan.

Fishya has a great classy atmosphere with light jazz playing in the background. I thought it might be more pricy than regular restaurants around town, but to my surprise I definitely got my money's worth here! We ordered the sushi roll lunch special, 3 rolls for $11. It's such a great deal.

Foods are nice and staffs are really kind. 
I definitely say the best sushi in town.
You guys should try Korean chicken wings. It is dope!!!!
Great service.  Food is good but we're from Chicago so hey not the greatest Asian / Japanese I've had

We went to this place to try some Korean food. My husband loves soon dobu so he wanted to try it here. But unfortunately they don't serve it anymore there. So he had Gamja tang instead. The soup was good and flavorful. I had Galbi tang and it was very tasty. We shared Galbi also. Galbi was very meaty. I think their Galbi was the meatiest among other Korean restaurants in West Lafayette. I liked the decor of restaurant. Our server was very friendly. Overall we really liked this restaurant.
My lunch bento box is not bad, my friend's bibimbap is amazing. The appetizers are fine, rice cake sauce is not thick enough, takoyaki is a little pricey. Will come back for bibimbap.

Dont get me wrong...the FOOD IS GOOD! BUT the service is bad. The waitress was chatting with the sushi chef for a long time and ignoring us. Our water wasnt filled and it took at least 2 to 3 attempts to get her attention. On the other side, her colleague was bussing other tables tirelessly while she chatted away. Props to that waiter for his hardwork.

reviews.text:
This review is for the food and the service provided during this Covid-19 issue. 

We ordered from Hunter's using their online order form that we found on their FB page. The ordering process was very simple and a full menu, as well as beer, is available.  The order form gives you the opportunity to customize your sandwiches.  For example "sauce on the side" is an option.  

We ordered the pub chicken sandwich with chips and the High 5 grilled cheese with waffle fries.   My wife got her sauce on the side and I was able to remove the provolone cheese and add bacon. We ordered and the website told us our order would be ready in 15 minutes and gave the instructions on how to pick up.  We arrived at the 15 minute mark, called to let them know we were there, and they brought our order right out. 

We drove to a local park to eat and our food was still hot and good as always!

Hunter's has done a good job of adjusting for the current situation.

Writing an update in regards to the COVID-19 adaption Hunter's Pub has made--I'm pretty impressed. I missed their darling nachos grande so we decided to order some for take out and Hunter's did several things right. They not only had the food warm and ready for us to pick up, they packed moist towelettes, napkins, plasticware, and did not skimp out on the food. The amount was as much as we would have if eating in. They seemed really appreciative of our support for their local business.

Decided to try this place out with my BF for some good take out after cooking at home for awhile and to support local businesses. This was our first time and we were looking forward to trying it out. The lady who took our order was very nice and the food was ready in less than 15 minutes. Then we checked our order and found out our half-pound, $11 boneless chicken appetizer only had 10 small chicken pieces. Maybe they were half a pound but I don't think so. We asked the lady and she said that it's always 10 wings to a order so I don't understand why they can't just write that on the menu instead of "half-pound" of chicken as it's misleading. The burger and fries were pretty good so I didn't want to review them low due to how good service was and the food was not bad. Just very disappointed by the chicken as it was an appetizer that didn't come with any additional sides besides celery.

So new owner at Hunters. I'm really liking what I see. Joy is very involved. I see her cleaning and scrubbing and asking questions. We chatted today and her statement that really won me over, "I want Hunters to be the place our customers deserve."  I'm looking forward to the great changes that are in store at Hunters. As always solid food, great beer selection and well stocked bar

Ordered tenderloin- prime rib sandwich and a prime rib steak dinner . I called them back as soon as I got home and realized this is NOT a prime rib . It's more like an old rib eye . The Cesar salad was less then good due to the amount of water in it . The tenderloin was over cooked  and waffle fries . The prime rib sandwich was ok .. and had to feed 2 of us to make up for the bad steak . 
I called the place back to explain the problems and even sent a text to show him the pic and was only offered 2 -$5 gift cards for the next visit . ( even though the dinner was $19.99)  the baked potato was also old and brown . Very disappointed in the results and spending $45 on poor food .
Nice local place but the food is just average. The catfish was like eating a slab of salt. The grilled veggies were good. Nice selection of beer. Staff was friendly.

Solid pub. Stopped in for their "Meatloaf Thursday"; meatloaf was phenomenal, and House green beans were great. Attractive, clean interior. Service was warm and friendly. If you are in the area, stop in; you won't be disappointed.

I've now been here three times, and I feel like I can give them a solid 4 stars.  We discovered that if you sit on the left side of the self-seat restaurant, it's the "drinking" area, so the waitstaff doesn't see you.  We ended up leaving in a hungry huff, but later realized it was kind of on us.  That said, the restaurant probably should've noticed that two people were sitting there with no drinks and looking around....or put up a sign that says "Bar service this way, restaurant service that way."  I took off half a star for this mix up.

The second and third times were solid.  I got the same dish both times, and was pleased with the portion size; I walked out super full.  The onion rings are large and battered, which I appreciate more that the crumb coating.  The chicken parm sandwich was yummy.  Spouse had a hamburger the first time, and a frisco melt the second time. In his words, 'They're okay, dawg."  Which, translated, means, "They were okay, but not so good that I won't try something else next time."

The other half star was taken off because of the way they label their bathrooms.  The men's room is labeled "Hunter," and the women's room is labeled "Hunted."  We live in a post-#MeToo era, and this seems pretty tone-deaf.  I don't really want a bar reminding me that it's a place where I could be "hunted" by their other clientele.

Hunters is a mixed bag for me, but I think four stairs is fair based on overall food quality, value, beer/food selection, and furnishings. I've been here six or eight times over the years and decided to finally write a review. 

I had the black-n-blue burger, well done, with fries. The burger was cooked through without being burnt. The blue cheese was sharp and added good taste and texture. Lettuce and tomato garnish was super fresh. The bun was nothing spectacular, it did not hold up to the weight of the burger or my cutting the sandwich, but did its job and held the burger and toppings together. The fries were a disappointment. These were overcooked and lukewarm. Definitely had been sitting in the fry pile for a while and dried out. There is no excuse for a pub not serving fresh piping hot fries. A disappointment that should drop this review to three stars, but the quality of the second meal buoyed my score.

My partner had the chicken quesadilla dinner plate, which came with refried beans, rice, some lettuce and sour cream, and a side of salsa too spicy to eat. Very good dish and we had enough quesadilla left for a take home snack. The entire place seemed to be staffed with one bartender and two servers. They kept up with the full house remarkably well. Overall a good value for the price, both meals under $10. My partner got the usual overpriced soda but the server kept it full.

This pub draws mostly graduate students and the 40-65 year old crowd, local professionals and married folk on a dates or girls night out. There are exceptions, both younger and older, but it's definitely not a college bar. Hunters is a decent pub that benefits from its location, large menu, and lack of competition in this busy commuter corridor loaded with strip-mall and small businesses. The interior is nothing special: a lot of wood, TVs, and chalkboard signage. It's quite boring actually but the pre-geriatric crowd doesn't seem fazed in the slightest.

I'm not a fan, as four stars suggests, but Hunters is a safe bet. Hard to go wrong with this local establishment. Final verdict: 3.5 stars and I'm rounding up due to value. Give me hot fresh fries, and it's four stars fo realz, yo!
No, thank you. I left immediately after seeing the bathroom signs. My buffalo chicken wrap was fine... but then I vomited after I saw those signs so the food really isn't my issue at all.

This pub is a staple in West Lafayette and is a great to place to go for lunch or dinner. There are plenty of TV's to watch sports and enjoy the big game. The food menu is very extensive and should be able to please any taste buds. My favorite here is the fish and chips (catfish fingers and fries). Be sure to get the fries cajun style for extra zing. In addition to the great food, they have plenty of beer, wine and liquor options. 

The servers and bartenders are great here and are very attentive.  They take very good care of you and keep your drinks full. If you are in town to see the Boilers, visiting friends/family or just to hang out...make sure you stop by Hunter's to grab some food and a drink! You won't regret it.

This is a dive local to Lafayette and they have great food! I don't usually do fish anywhere on the planet but HP's breaded catfish dinner is just to die for. It tastes the same every time and enough for two if you get the 2 piece meal.

Although it states this place is not good for kids, no where does it state you must be 21 to eat here.   Spent an hour trying to decide where to have dinner.  Not an easy feet with multiple food allergies 

No where on yelp OR THE main page does it state this.  

What a waste of our time
Change your bathroom signs. Seriously. Like someone else said, it's disgusting and tone deaf to suggest that women should be "hunted". Really uncool.

We've been here several times and, generally both the food and service are good. They have a very large menu so some things will be pretty good and others will be not so good. The menu is less creative and the food isn't as good as Digby's, but if you are looking for a solid, no frills, meal then this is a good place to eat.

Great spot for locals and Purdue students! The prices are super reasonable and the staff is funny and attentive. Their fries are fantastic! One small thing is that the bathroom signs are kinda sexist with the men's room being labeled "Hunter" and the women's says "The Hunted". It's 2018, that's gross. But the food, atmosphere, drink specials, and deals are great!

I wish I lived in West Lafayette - I would come here all the time. Food was sooo good and the portions were very, very generous. The pork tenderloin sandwich (three little pigs) was perhaps one of the best I've had. Ordered it with waffle fries which were also delicious.  Let me also recommend quesadillas for the appetizer.

Hunter's Pub on the West Side is my favorite place to grab a good burger and fries. There are several other tasty items on the menu - which has a ton of variety. Sandwiches, Mexican food, lots of appetizers and more complete dinners are also available. 

Make no mistake, this is a sports bar. Several TVs have different games playing and the staff will gladly change a channel to play your game for you. 

Food is consistently good and service is fast and friendly.

This is a popular local place to grab a bite to eat. Service is always great and very friendly. Having said that, food is good, but isn't exactly unique. That's probably why I like Hunters Pub: there are no surprises.

I'm a huge fan of Hunters. I'm vegetarian and Hunters is one of few restaurants with multiple options in this town. Our server is always friendly. The drink specials are amazing. And the price is on point. My meal usually costs $9 and I have leftovers for the next day. The caveat is that it's greasy bar food but they are good for that and don't claim to be anything else.

reviews.text: Fuel's new location is much more open than the previous one, but I miss the downtown funk. The coffee drinks are just as good. There is also outside seating which they did not have before. There is a small lot with 3-4 spots reserved for Fuel, but most customers are student walk ups. Nice location but I will miss Fuel downtown.
Pleasant location. The coffee I had was great and I'm really digging the interior. Their hours are a little bit out of my way so I haven't been able to come here as much as I want to.

Easy going campus coffee spot providing a smart alternative to Greyhouse and Vienna with more space and better prices for the quality than either. Parking is more awkward however and as the limited hours. I really enjoy their Miel and various roasts here. Plenty to cater to caffeine needs and fantastic friendly service with easy to use rewards program.
A little busy during lunch hour during the semester, but their service is still speedy and friendly! I got an iced earl grey latte, which was delicious. 5/5 stars

I really enjoyed this unassuming coffee shop next to the Lutheran church! I ordered a masala chai with a shot of vanilla for $4.60, which came in a great size and was some of the best chai I've ever had. However, their earl grey latte had some sort of weird lavender soap-y aftertaste that I was not a huge fan of, but perhaps some people enjoy that flowery taste. I look forward to returning and trying more of their drinks, along with some of their food items.

Fuel is by far my favorite coffee shop in the West Lafayette area! I visit at least four times a week. The coffee is simply delicious, and they always have such a variety of roasts throughout the week. I typically just get a black coffee, but their chai tea lattes, flavored drinks, and teas are also excellent. This is the perfect place for studying, meeting, or just getting together with friends. There is always plenty of seating, and the baristas are always friendly. I cannot recommend this place highly enough!

Love this coffee shop! Best iced coffee in town! I didn't know this was there until recently, but I'm so glad I found it! My friends and I love the atmosphere for studying. Their iced coffee is amazing - the best I've had - and their food (especially their vegan chili) is a major bonus! Looking forward to stopping in here regularly during the upcoming school year.
Great place to get coffee and breakfast/brunch. Loved the Lafayette location!  Very nice, friendly. Pastries and muffins awesome. Very good coffee too!

reviews.text: MY FAVORITE RESTAURANT ON THE ENTIRE EARTH. The food here is amazing every single time! My fiancé and I love to come here for special occasion date nights and we always tell people that it is one of our favorite restaurants ever. We talked about it so much that our families joined us for a meal for a celebration we were having. They all enjoyed the food as well! My family is from out of town, and they were raving about their meal and how they couldn't wait to go back. They still talk about how good the food was! We always joke that we would make the 3 hour drive just for La Scala's food! It's that good!! I seriously cannot recommend this restaurant enough. I've only ever dined inside, and the atmosphere is really nice. It's quiet, intimate, and cozy. I would love to dine outside as well though! They have a really pretty patio area with lights. I can't wait to go back soon! I would also like to add that I am gluten free and they have great options for me, including gluten free dinner rolls!

Thank goodness for La Scala! As a born-and-raised Chicago girl, I require a higher than normal amount of cheese and carbs for daily survival (preferably in the form of pizza, but pasta will also suffice). I admit that I was a bit worried about finding good Italian food after moving to Indiana...but not anymore!

When you walk in the door of La Scala, the first thing that hits you is the ambiance. Like Pavlov's dogs, I've been conditioned to salivate when I hear the crooning voice of Sinatra, especially when combined with the smell of garlic in the air. Add in the warm and cozy atmosphere, friendly staff, and ample seating (indoor and out, weather permitting), and I was in heaven. I loooove their menu; I seriously have a list of about 10 items still to try, and had a lot of difficulty choosing which one to start with. Everything sounds SO good! On my first trip I had the pumpkin mac & cheese, with their apple cider cocktail drink. So much comfort food. It's like a hug on a plate! 

If you are looking for a great place to get that homecooked meal even if you're far from home, give La Scala a try. They're open for lunch and for dinner (they do close in between though, so be wary if you're looking for something between 2-5). They cater to special food restrictions, including gluten-free, so get on in there and eat!

Excellent dinner!  The menu is robust and great variety. The bread and olive oil is wonderful start to the meal. Each pasta comes with soup or salad. The entrees were plentiful. 

For entrees, my husband had the risotto and said it was outstanding!  I had the Miguel Angelo and was pleased. The sauce was a little thin but taste was delightful. My daughter had the gnocchi bolognese and loved it. 

Great restaurant right on the Lafayette square. Definitely make a reservation on a weekend as they were busy!  Always a good sign!

Can I just say how much I love that they have gluten-free options at the restaurant? Good, because I'm gonna. Italian food was my FAVORITE food before getting a gluten allergy. Now there are far and few dishes that I can enjoy at an Italian restaurant. Not anymore! La Scala is now my go-to place in Lafayette for gluten free pasta!

First of all, I love this building! Gothic archway and stained glass on the front entryway. Lovely outdoor seating area with the rustic charm of Italy itself. Did I also mention that they are farm to table and chef-owned? Yep, everything you could ever want to support in a local restaurant is here at La Scala!

I came here with some friends, and everyone LOVED their entrees and drinks. Definitely Try their lasagna. It's fresh, homemade and amazing! You also get your money's worth here. I couldn't finish all of my food, even though I wanted to. The server was very knowledgeable in what items were gluten-free, and if he didn't know he would go and ask the chef. Superb customer service. I can't wait for my next trip to Lafayette so I can sample more of what they have to offer for us gluten intolerant folks.

My best friend has raved about this place for years, but we had never tried it, so when we were picking a place to have a slightly belated Valentine's Day dinner (February 15th), I figured it was time to finally try La Scala.

The restaurant is small and intimate. I wouldn't really recommend it for groups. There are a few four seater tables, but it looked like most of the tables were for two. However, the tables are very close together (very European style), so if you're looking for a quiet place where you won't hear the conversations of people around you, this may not be the place for you. It wasn't too bad for us, although my chair was touching the chair of the woman behind me. The tables were lovely, set with white tablecloths and tea lights.

The meal starts with water an bread service. The bread does come with olive oil and spices for dipping (yum!), but the bread has olives in it, so if you're not an olive fan, be aware. You can pick most of them out if you want to though.

We didn't get any appetizers, though the shrimp and crab dip sounded really good (and then the table next to us ordered it, and it looked delicious, but my husband would never eat it and it was definitely too much for me!). I was torn between the seafood ravioli and the lobster & shrimp mac and cheese; our server recommended the mac and cheese, so that's what I went with. My husband ordered the pollo ripieno without the red pepper cream sauce.

My husband said his dish was very flavorful, even without the sauce. I absolutely LOVED the mac and cheese. The Grand Marnier cream sauce was lovely, the mozzarella on top was extra melty, and I thought the orange was a thoughtful (and tasty) touch. There was also way more seafood than I expected; there were whole shrimp, large chunks of lobster, and it seemed to be almost as much seafood as pasta!

Unfortunately, we had to cut our evening short (our babysitter called to say our youngest had gotten sick), but our server, Beau, was awesome about getting us the check quickly, boxing up the rest of my meal (I don't think I'd ever had someone else box up my leftovers for me before!), and getting me a cannoli to go (the cannoli was delicious, btw -- very smooth filling!).

Great food and great service makes La Scala a great choice!

Excellent food, excellent atmosphere, hit-or-miss service. Have celebrated valentine's day, multiple bridal shower/bachelorette dinners, birthdays, promotions, and more here. Have always enjoyed all the amazing food, and especially enjoy any of the tortellini dishes. The house sangria is really good.

La Scalia is always consistent with the quality of their meals. The whole atmosphere of the restaurant is very cozy and makes you feel like you aren't downtown. The food is delicious as well as the bread.

The food was fantastic. 
We had pastas - shrimp Alfredo and chicken asparagus in lemon cream.   Both came with large Caesar salads and crispy bread.

The patio is charming and tucked away so it is wind free.

The wine list is small but pleasant.

Too bad they close at 9pm.
When I'm in Lafayette LaScala is my choice.

I have been going here at least once every couple months and every time it's been great. They have a good selection of items on the menu, and the atmosphere is fancy and welcoming. The service is good and the overall experience is always enjoyable. One of the best Italian restaurants in the area for sure.

I have been here for dinner several times, but today I had lunch. Delicious! This might not seem like a typical lunch spot, but it is tasty and affordable...with options other than pasta. I had a cup of chicken vegetable soup and a Ceaser salad with bread, all for about $10. Local, fresh, friendly service and different. My friend had  an Italian veggie sandwich that she loved. Certainly worth supporting a great local restaurant.

First time here. La Scala is a farm to table restaurant. I went for lunch. I am not a real dressy person. I think dinner will be more dressy than casual. 

Rustic wood tables and upholstered chairs. 

Along with the pasta, sandwiches were on the menu. They looked good. 

I had the Ravioli Florentine in cream sauce sun-dried tomatoes and spinach. 

A small salad of field greens cucumber and carrots dressed in homemade balsamic vinaigrette came first.  Very tasty. 

With the ravioli a homemade personal loaf of herbed bread was served. Soft and fluffy with a crispy bottom. Mmm. 

Meal finished for under $17 with tip, no alcohol. 

I will return. 

The one problem is the parking. It is downtown Lafayette with street parking

We sat outside which was beautiful but the chairs were super uncomfy. The inside is dark and odd looking. It took a while for our food to come out which was disappointing. The seafood ravioli was good, but a bit strange and not a classic Italian taste. Good price. Amazing service!! Rebecca, our server was phenomenal!! Super kind, very professional. She accommodated my vegetarian needs and took her time with us.

My last experience was bad. I came here to order one more time staffed calamari. They were total different from the one month ago. Taste and look.In menu states that they suppose be staffed with crab meat and shrimp, I even didn't noticed any of those. The portion of this was also small. To pay over 20$ for rice-no thank you! I suggest the cook chief was different which make me disappointed. The waiter told me she will bring me more, never shown up with this. The service this visit was not the best either. Have feeling that  I'm not appreciated cus

Came here on a random week night with coworkers.  Heard good things about it from locals and thought we would try it out.  Ordered an appetizer that never arrived but luckily we also were not charged for it.  Entrees were mediocre but smothered in sauces and cheese.  Sauces were thick but not rich.    Flavor fell a little short too.  Dessert was the saving grace as the cannoli was legitimately good and quite authentic.  Wine selection was fine and they were kind enough to offer sampling's as well to my coworker who was undecided.  Menu is vast and offers something for all.  It seems to be a local staple restaurant and family owned.

I was in town for business and looked on Yelp for a dinner recommendation.  La Scala looked like my kind of place, so I headed there.  I sat at the bar and was greeted by James, who provided excellent t service.  They have a large menu, so it was tough to make a choice.  I wound up with the old standby, Veal Parmigiana.  I started with a house salad, which was very good with the balsamic vinaigrette dressing.  Their bread is also delicious with a good olive oil dipping sauce.  My veal was perfect...terrific tomato sauce with a perfect level of spice.  Good size portion and very reasonable prices.  Nice wine list as well.  La Scala is a great choice for Italian when in Lafayette!

This restaurant had the best energy and from the very beginning I knew that I'd love it. My server's name was pronounced 'Bow' not completely sure how he spells it. He answered all of my questions regarding the menu, he brought multiple samples of wine and even suggested his favs. Everything was to my liking and when the food finally came it was piping hot and delicious! The calamari was fresh and crispy. My white broccoli and cheddar soup was so good my friends sent their salads back and requested the soup togo. I'm definitely a "eat in bed" kind of girl so I took majority of my food togo so i coild eat it in bed . it was literally so good I couldn't enjoy it in a restaurant, it's definitely a comfort meal so i needed to be comfy. The Restaurant had low lights and soft music playing the vibe was LOVELY! Also there was lots of nice artwork hanging all throughout the restaurant. I'd definitely recommend. Ask for "Bow" or "Beau"
We love this place! Farm to table at its best. Plus the outdoor seating is . If you go - definitely get the bruschetta.

Who knew that most restaurants would be closed the week of July 4th? Luckily La Scala was open! We had a great dinner with homemade blue cheese dressing, homemade sauces and pasta. All of the entrees were great, and our server was lovely. Would definitely go back if I lived in Lafayette (we live in San Francisco).

Along with Red Seven and Bistro 501, this has to be one of the most well-to-do places in downtown Lafayette. I suggest getting your special event reservations for this place too a few months early.

Very classic Italian in both aesthetic, ambiance, and food. It's really cute inside, with the art, brick, and dark wood. Though the dining rooms are quite narrow, the high ceilings make up for it and the setting is actually quite intimate. Like Red Seven, the ambiance is quite flexible. You can go there casually with friends, but also on a date or professionally. It does feel a little more mature, classier, or kind of meant for older people, but you definitely get plenty of college students cycling through. On warmer nights, they also have the enclosed outdoor seating with fairy lights, and on warm nights it is its own kind of beautiful.

If you want something light, get something with the lemon sauce and pair it with their limoncello. However, my favorite is anything with the wine cream sauce. But ingredients are fresh, the pasta is handmade, and they really have something for everyone. Actually, honestly there isn't anything here I don't like. At the end of the meal, I like to have one of their desserts. Tiramisu (which is apparently imported) for dessert if you want to have something absolutely gorgeous at the end. The cannoli is good too, but you can get an equally delicious one at Vienna (coffee shop) for cheaper. They have different kinds of the fresh bread on different days, though I'm not sure of the scheduling a the moment.

The wait staff are WONDERFUL. In my rush, I once forgot my credit card at La Scala, and they held onto it for me until I got it back. Even better, they verified my identity before doing it, which I appreciate. Also, I had this one incident with some friends and their family where the numbers kept shifting (some people got stuck in traffic) and we sat down to eat and then they came, and then some didn't--the point is that the staff were SUPER accommodating. Not to mention they just rolled with whatever kind of diet the people I brought/with threw at them.

For a smaller taste, check them out at the downtown food festival Lafayette holds every summer. They almost always have a booth there. Best bet is to park in the garage behind Red Seven. From there, take the doors into the bank offices (I've never actually seen them lock), and walk out through the lobby. It'll place you smack dab on the street corner where you just cross the street and you're pretty much there.

So we walked by this place Saturday and it was quite busy in the courtyard and it smelled heavenly. We were with our freshman who would not have appreciated the deliciousness inside so we went elsewhere. We were going to be here for two more nights. Closed Sunday but went back Monday night. It was again quite busy. The very friendly host found us a table outside and since they were short on staff waited on us himself. 

The bread was a nice treat to start. I had the beef canneloni. I love that they use local ingredients including the beef. The tricolor pasta sheets were a thing to behold. I did not waste a bite of this dish. There is so much that I wanted to try on that menu I'm sure I'll get something different next time but maybe not. Loved sitting outside in the courtyard.
